sp.p: Did you ſee him there all the while?

sp.speaker: Mr. Thornton.
sp.p: Yes, I did ſee him every day, I believe, in the Refectory at Dinner time, and at Night in the Dormitory, where all the Collegians have their Beds, I lay over againſt him every Night, I ſaw him particularly upon the day of Hilſley's departure, which was the 24th of April New Stile, and I ſaw him the firſt of May New Stile, upon the coming of Mr. Bournaby to the Colledge; and particularly again I remember him there the 2d of May, when my Schoolfellows exhibited an Action or Play.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Was Mr. Oates there then?

sp.speaker: Mr. Thornton.
sp.p: Yes, I ſaw him preſent at it, and I know it by this particular Circumſtance, there was a ſcufflle between him and another about a place to ſee the Play.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jenes.
sp.p: Did you ſee him the 23d of April Old Style, that is, the third of May New Style, which was the day after your Play, that you remember?

sp.speaker: Mr. Thornton.
sp.p: I do not remember that I did ſee him that day, by any particular circumſtance, though I believe I did.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jones.
sp.p: Do you remember when Mr. Poole came away from St. Omers?

sp.speaker: Mr. Thornton.
sp.p: Yes, I do.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jones.
sp.p: When was that?

sp.speaker: Mr. Thornton.
sp.p: The 5th of May New Style.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jones.
sp.p: Was Oates at St. Omers at that time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Thornton.
sp.p: Yes, he was there then, I am ſure.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Was not he Reader there in the Colledge?

sp.speaker: Mr. Thornton.
sp.p: He was Reader in the Sodality, and to my knowledge, he did not miſs once from the 24th of April New Style, to the 24th of May New Style, from being there, and reading in the Sodality.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What did he uſe to read?

sp.speaker: Mr. Thornton.
sp.p: Some Spiritual Book or piece of Divinity, or the like, as it was uſual to have read every Sunday and Holidy.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And that is one reaſon why you conclude he was there all that while, becauſe every Sunday and Holiday he was to read, and did read.

sp.speaker: Mr. Thornton.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray my Lord, be pleaſed to ask this Gentleman what Religion he is of.

sp.speaker: Mr. Thornton.
sp.p: A Roman Catholick.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Where does he live?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where do you live Mr. Thornton?

sp.speaker: Mr. Thornton.
sp.p: I am a Northumberland man, that's my Country.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Mr. Lord, I deſire to know of him, when he did come from St. Omers?

sp.speaker: Mr. Thornton.
sp.p: I came from St. Omers, my Lord, about two years after that Oates went away from thence.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray my Lord, be pleaſed to ask him, who it was that was Rector or Governour of that Houſe or Colledge.

sp.speaker: Mr. Thornton.
sp.p: It was one Mr. Richard Aſhby.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray my Lord, be pleaſed to ask him, what School he was in there.

sp.speaker: Mr. Thornton.
sp.p: I was in Sintaxe, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Then my Lord, I would ask him another queſtion, and that is this, whether he was not a Witneſs in behalf of the five Jeſuits and Mr. Langhorn.

sp.speaker: Mr. Thornton.
sp.p: No, I was not, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire to know, if he can tell the occaſion of Mr. Hilſley coming away from St. Omers.

sp.speaker: Mr. Thornton.
sp.p: It never concerned me at all, and I never enquired into it.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Then my Lord, I would ask him this queſtion, why he is ſo preciſe as to his Remembrance of what was done in April and May, when he does not give any account of any other time, nor did the other Witneſſes.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Yes, but they do; they give you a particular account from the time of your coming thither, which was about Chriſtmas, ſome ſay the latter end of November, or the beginning of December, they are not poſitive to any particular time, but thereabouts, and ſo from that time all along till June.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: I beg your Lordſhips pardon, I did not hear that he ſaid any ſuch thing.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: If you will, I'll ask him that queſtion again for your ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: If you pleaſe, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Then mind what is ſaid; Do you remember that Oates was there in March before, and in February before?

sp.speaker: Mr. Thornton.
sp.p: Yes, I particularly remember in March before, he did read a Ridiculous Book in the Sodality, and he was remarkable in the Houſe by twenty Ridiculous paſſages.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: I do acknowledge I did in March read a pleaſant Book, called The Contempt of the Clergy.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: By whoſe Order did he read that Book in the Sodality?

sp.speaker: Mr. Thornton.
sp.p:
I do not know, whether it was by his own election that he was
Reader there, or by the Command of the Prefect of the Studies, that has the Care of the Students, and appoints them their Buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray my Lord, be pleaſed to ask him how long he was Reſident at St. Omers.

sp.speaker: Mr. Thornton.
sp.p: I was there ſeven years.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You ſaid he was there in June till Midſummer Eve.

sp.speaker: Mr. Thornton.
sp.p: Yes, he was ſo.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: I own that I was there in June, but that was after I returned from England.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When do you ſay he left the Colledge firſt?

sp.speaker: Mr. Thornton.
sp.p: He never left the Colledge from the time of his coming thither firſt till Midſummer Eve, only one time that he was at Watton, and that was but a day or two at moſt, which is not a League out of Town.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do you remember him there about Chriſtmas time.

sp.speaker: Mr. Thornton.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, very well.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When was it he went to Watton?

sp.speaker: Mr. Thornton.
sp.p: About the latter end of January (as I do remember) and in February above Shrovetide I remember him particularly to be there.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Now Mr. Oates, you ſee he ſpeaks to other times beſides April and May, and he brings, upon my word, very notable circumſtances.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: He ſays he went to School with me there, I think, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. Thornton.
sp.p: No, I ſay he was in the ſame Colledge.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But not in the ſame Claſſis, for it ſeems you were in the Rhetorick Form, and he in the Syntax.

sp.speaker: Mr. Thornton.
sp.p: My Lord, he went there by reaſon of his Age, and upon no other account; he might have gone elſewhere with us who were of a lower Form, for any great ſtore of Learning he had.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You hear him, I ſuppoſe, Mr. Oates, he gives no great commendation of your Scholarſhip.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: That is nothing to this queſtion; but pray my Lord, be pleaſed to ask him, whether he did not hear of a Conſult of the Jeſuits held here in England in April 78.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What ſay you Sir, Did you hear of any ſuch Conſult?

sp.speaker: Mr. Thornton.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I did hear of a Triennial Congregation, ſuch as uſed to be held by them, but that did not belong to me to enquire into it.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire to know of whom he did hear it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How do you know there was ſuch a Conſult, who told you of it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Thornton.
sp.p: I heard of it in the Houſe, and I had read that it was the Cuſtom of that Society of People to have ſuch a meeting once in three years.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray for what purpoſe did they ſo meet?

sp.speaker: Mr. Thornton.
sp.p: As I have been told, It was to ſend a Procurator to Rome, and for their managing their other Affairs, which concern'd their Society.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Have the Jeſuits uſually ſuch a Conſult once in three years Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. Thornton.
sp.p: I was never preſent at any ſuch Congregation, I was not capable of it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But was it us'd to be ſaid ſo?

sp.speaker: Mr. Thornton.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I have heard it ſaid ſo, and read of it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Mr. Oates, Will you ask him any more queſtions?

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: No, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well then, go on Mr. Attorney, and call another Witneſs.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Swear Mr. William Conway (which was done.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Mr. Conway, pray will you give my Lord and the Jury an account where you were in the year 1677. and in the year 1678.

sp.speaker: Mr. Conway.
sp.p: I was then at St. Omers, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Do you remember Mr. Oates there at any time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Conway.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I do.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Pray at what time was he there as you remember?

sp.speaker: Mr. Conway.
sp.p: He came in December before Chriſtmas 1677. and did not go away till June 1678.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: What time in June did he go away?

sp.speaker: Mr. Conway.
sp.p: About the twentieth of June, I think.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Were you there all that year?

sp.speaker: Mr. Conway.
sp.p: Yes, I was there a Scholar in the Colledge.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jones.
sp.p: Was he all the time you ſpeak of in the Colledge?

sp.speaker: Mr. Conway.
sp.p: He lay out one night.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: What time was that?

sp.speaker: Mr. Conway.
sp.p: In January, to the beſt of my remembrance.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Could he be out of the Colledge any time and not be miſt?

sp.speaker: Mr. Conway.
sp.p: No, my Lord, he could not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Did you miſs him at any time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Conway.
sp.p: No, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Was he there in April 1678?

sp.speaker: Mr. Conway.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Can you tell any particular paſſages that can make you remember it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Conway.
sp.p: Yes my Lord, I can.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Tell my Lord and the Jury how you can remember it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Conway.
sp.p: I remember Mr. Hilſley's departure, which was the 24th of April New Style, and ſoon after Mr. Bournaby came, but I do not know the time exactly, I was deſirous to know of Mr. Bournaby whether he met Mr. Hilſley upon the way, and he told me he did meet him, and the next day I ſaw Mr. Oates and Mr. Bournaby walking together very familiarly, and I took particular notice of it at that time, Mr. Bournaby being but newly come, ſo that I took him to have known Mr. Bournaby before, or elſe I concluded him to be a little impudent by his intruding into his company.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Do you remember him in March before?

sp.speaker: Mr. Conway.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: What particulars do you remember of his being there then?

sp.speaker: Mr. Conway.
sp.p: I remember him to be there on the Thurſday in Mid-Lent, the Scholars in the Colledge had a particular Recreation, which they call, Sawing of the Witch, and Mr. Oates was among them, and I was one of them that broke a Pan about his head for Recreation.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Do you remember the firſt of May, that there was in your Colledge a Play acted?

sp.speaker: Mr. Conway.
sp.p: As for the Play, I remember what part Eſquire Pool acted in it, but I remember not any particulars that can make me ſo ſure as to ſwear that Oates were there.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Do you remember any ſcuffling for a place there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Conway.
sp.p: I do not remember it of my own knowledge, I heard of it afterwards.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: You ſay that you ſaw Mr. Bournaby and him walking together the next day after he came.

sp.speaker: Mr. Conway.
sp.p: Yes, I did ſo Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Did Oates uſe to read in the Sodality?

sp.speaker: Mr. Conway.
sp.p: My Lord, there was another choſen according to the Cuſtom to read, but Mr. Oates took the Book, and did read.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Did he read conſtantly?

sp.speaker: Mr. Conway.
sp.p: I did never miſs him any Sunday or Holyday all the time.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: From what time to what time did he read?

sp.speaker: Mr. Conway.
sp.p: From a little after Eaſter till he went away.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Is it uſually taken notice of in the Colledge when any perſon who is a Student goes away from the Colledge?

sp.speaker: Mr. Conway.
sp.p: There is nothing more diſcourſed of among Scholars, than that when it happens any one goes out of the Colledge.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And pray when did he go away?

sp.speaker: Mr. Conway.
sp.p: In June, about the twentieth, as near as I can remember.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Did you obſerve him at Dinner there conſtantly?

sp.speaker: Mr. Conway.
sp.p: Yes, he ſate by himſelf.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: How came that to paſs?

sp.speaker: Mr. Conway.
sp.p: He ſate at a little Table in the Hall by himſelf, for he pretended, being a man in years, he could not Diet as the reſt of the young Students did, and therefore obtained leave to ſit alone at a little Table by himſelf, and he ſate next to the Table of the Fathers, to which all the Students were to make their Reverence before they ſate down.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He was a very Remarkable man by his ſitting by himſelf; Did he ſit there alwaies?

sp.speaker: Mr. Conway.
sp.p: He changed his Table once, and I took notice that he ſate on the other ſide of the Refectory.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: When was that I pray, can you remember?

sp.speaker: Mr. Conway.
sp.p: That was a little after Eaſter.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Will Mr. Oates ask him any Queſtions?

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray my Lord will you ask this Gentleman what Religion he is of?

sp.speaker: Mr. Conway.
sp.p: I am a Roman Catholick.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray ask him where he lives.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where do you live Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. Conway.
sp.p: Where now at preſent my Lord?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where do you uſually live?

sp.speaker: Mr. Conway.
sp.p: I am a Flintſhire man, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray ask him what Name he did go by at St. Omers.

sp.speaker: Mr. Conway.
sp.p: By the name of William Parry.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray ask him by what name he gave his Evidence in at the five Jeſuits Tryal.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Were you a Witneſs at the Tryal of the five Jeſuits?

sp.speaker: Mr. Conway.
sp.p: Yes, I was.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: By what name did you give your Evidence there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Conway.
sp.p: By the name of Parry.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Then I deſire the Court to take notice he repreſented himſelf by a feigned name in a Court of Record.

sp.speaker: Mr. Conway.
sp.p: I went by both names, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, make what advantage you can of it by and by.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray my Lord ask him, if ever he heard of any Conſult of the Jeſuits held here in England in April 1678?

sp.speaker: Mr. Conway.
sp.p: Yes, I did.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray my Lord ask him, who inform'd him of that Conſult.

sp.speaker: Mr. Conway.
sp.p: I heard it among the reſt of the Scholars, and ſeeing ſome of the Fathers go over to it, I was told ſo.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Is it an uſual thing for them to have ſuch meetings?

sp.speaker: Mr. Conway.
sp.p: They have a Congregation ordinarily once in three years.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Does it go by the name of a Conſult, or what name has it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Conway.
sp.p: Some call it a Congregation, and ſome a Conſult.

sp.speaker: M. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: What is the end of ſuch meeting, as you have heard?

sp.speaker: Mr. Conway.
sp.p: They ſay it was to chuſe a Procurator to ſend to Rome, and give an account of the Province.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I would ask him another queſtion, whether he is to have any Reward for giving this Evidence here.

sp.speaker: Mr. Conway.
sp.p: No, not that I know of, but what I expect from Almighty God.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray ask him how long he lived at St. Omers.

sp.speaker: Mr. Conway.
sp.p: Five years.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I have done with him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Then call Mr. Haggerſtone, and ſwear him, (which was done.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Mr. Haggerſtone, pray will you acquaint my Lord and the Jury, were you at St. Omers in the year 1678. with Mr. Oates?

sp.speaker: Mr. Haggerſtone.
sp.p: Yes, I was my Lord, I had the honour to be of the ſame Bench with the Doctor of Salamanca.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You mean you were of the ſame Claſs with him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Haggerſtone.
sp.p: Yes my Lord, of the ſame Claſs.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: In what year was it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Haggerſtone.
sp.p: In the year 1678.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: In what Form were you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Haggerſtone.
sp.p: In the ſame Bench with Doctor Oates in the Rhetorick Form.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Do you remember Mr. Oates in April 1678?

sp.speaker: Mr. Haggerſtone.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Haggerſtone.
sp.p: He ſpoke unto me on the 25th of April.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What Style do you mean?

sp.speaker: Mr. Haggerſtone.
sp.p:
New Style Sir, to avoid confuſion, I ſpeak of the Style of the place where I was; he asked me concerning our School-fellow Mr. Hilſley, who was then gone from the Colledge, whether I had heard any thing from him ſince he
went away, and he ſpoke of an indiſpoſition he had, for which he preſcribed him a Medicine of Poppy, and he thought it would do his buſineſs effectually.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who ſaid ſo?

sp.speaker: Mr. Haggerſtone.
sp.p: The Doctor of Salamanca, he was called Sampſon Lucy in the Colledge, and likewiſe he forbid him to chew Tobacco, which he us'd to do very much; he was called Titus Ambroſius, he had twenty Names.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Was he there all April Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. Haggerſtone.
sp.p: Yes, he was Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did you know him in March before?

sp.speaker: Mr. Haggerſtone.
sp.p: Yes, he was there all March before.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Was he there in February?

sp.speaker: Mr. Haggerſtone.
sp.p: Yes, as near as I can remember, he was abſent but one day, and then he went to Watton in February, or elſe in January.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do you remember when he came thither firſt?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hagggerſtone.
sp.p: Yes my Lord, he came in December near Chriſtmas as I remember.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was it about that time, upon your Oath?

sp.speaker: Mr. Haggerſtone.
sp.p: I ſpeak it upon my Oath, it was.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When did he go away?

sp.speaker: Mr. Haggerſtone.
sp.p: About the latter end of June.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was he abſent any time between December and June?

sp.speaker: Mr. Haggerſtone.
sp.p: I do not remember that he was abſent, ſave only in January or February, and that was not for above a night, when he went to Watton.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Might not he be abſent, and you not mind it, or know it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Haggerſtone.
sp.p: Sure if he had been abſent, we could not but have known it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How ſo, pray you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Haggerſtone.
sp.p: If any goes away, 'tis ſo publick, that it cannot be without notice being taken of it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Can you remember by any particular token he was there in April or May?

sp.speaker: Mr. Haggerstone.
sp.p: He ſpoke to me on the 29th of April New Style, and told me, that there was a Craving Engliſh-man had been there to beg an Alms, and there was a Collection made for him among the Scholars, but he ſaid he would give him nothing, for he told me he had been cheated by ſuch an one of ſome Pieces of Eight in Spain; this I remember was the 28th or 29th of April New Style, I ſaw him there the firſt of May, upon the ſecond of May there was an Action of the Scholars, and he was preſent at it; the fifth of May I was at School with him, when Mr. Pool went away for England, and I heard him about that time preach a pleaſant Sermon, for he would undertake ſometimes to preach, and he ſaid in it, That the late King Charles the Second halted betwixt two Opinions, and a ſtream of Popery went between his Leggs

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was this in May?

sp.speaker: Mr. Haggerstone.
sp.p: Yes, juſt after Mr. Pool went away for England, and he had ſome pretty Reflections in his Sermon about Toby's Dogg wagging his Tail.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, do you ask this Witneſs any queſtion, Mr. Oates?

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray be pleaſed to ask him, my Lord, what Religion he is of.

sp.speaker: Mr. Haggerstone.
sp.p: I am a Papiſt, my Lord, I am not aſham'd of it.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray my Lord, ask where he lives.

sp.speaker: Mr. Haggerstone.
sp.p: At London.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray ask him what Country-man he is.

sp.speaker: Mr. Haggerstone.
sp.p: I am a Northumberland man, my Father is Sir Thomas Haggerſtone, a man better known than your Father, Doctor Oates.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Nay, nay, do not be in a paſſion man.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray ask him how long I was with him at St. Omers.

sp.speaker: Mr. Haggerstone.
sp.p: For half a year at leaſt.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire to know how long he ſtayed there himſelf.

sp.speaker: Mr. Haggerstone.
sp.p: I ſtudied my whole Courſe of Humanity there.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How long were you there in all?

sp.speaker: Mr. Haggerstone.
sp.p: Seven years.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray my Lord ask him, whether he knows of any Conſult held, or to be held here in England in April 1678.

sp.speaker: Mr. Haggerstone.
sp.p:
Yes, my Lord, I ſaw two of the Fathers go from St. Omers
to the Congregation, and was there at their return, but all that time I frequented Doctor Oates's company, and he remained in the Colledge.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray who were theſe two Fathers?

sp.speaker: Mr. Haggerstone.
sp.p: Mr. Williams and Mr. Marſh; and when they return'd, Oates asked me about it, whether they had been at the Conſult, and I told him there was ſuch a thing, but he never knew it till afterwards; but this I am ſure of, he was never miſſing all the while, I ſate on the ſame Bench with him.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray my Lord ask him, what name he went by at St. Omers.

sp.speaker: Mr. Haggerstone.
sp.p: I went by the name of Harry Howard, my Mother was a Howard, Doctor.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray ask him whether he came into England when he went away from thence.

sp.speaker: Mr. Haggerstone.
sp.p: No, I went and ſtudied my Philoſophy at Doway.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: I deſire to ask him one queſtion more.

sp.speaker: Mr. Haggerstone.
sp.p: Twenty, if you pleaſe, Doctor.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: I deſire to know of him the occaſion of Mr. Hilſley's coming away.

sp.speaker: Mr. Haggerstone.
sp.p: I do know it, but truly I cannot tell whether it be fit for me to ſpeak of it, it was upon ſome unhandſome account, but I muſt not blemiſh any Gentleman, I think.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I will ask him one queſtion more, whether ever he was admitted into the Society.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I will not ask him that queſtion, how often have I told you no ſuch queſtions are to be ask'd? muſt I make him liable to Penalty? No, ask queſtions that are fair, and you ſhall have a fair anſwer.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I have done then with him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Then ſwear Mr. Robert Beeſton, (which was done.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray Sir, were you at St. Omers in the year 77. and 78?

sp.speaker: Mr. Beeſton.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did you ſee Mr. Oates there then? do you know him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Beeſton.
sp.p: Yes, I know him very well, I did ſee him there.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What months did you ſee him there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Beeſton.
sp.p: He came there in December, the beginning as I remember, and he ſtayed there to June the latter end.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What years was that in?

sp.speaker: Mr. Beeſton.
sp.p: He came in 77. and went away in 78.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did you obſerve him to be there in April and May 78?

sp.speaker: Mr. Beeſton.
sp.p: The latter end of April, and the beginning of May I did.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Tell the Court particularly how you remember it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Beeſton.
sp.p: My Lord, I ſaw him the firſt of May at St Omers, where he played at Nine-pins, and I laid a wager upon the ſame ſide that he did, and loſt my money as well as he.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do you remember any other time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Beeſton.
sp.p: I ſaw him the ſecond of May, by the ſame token that I met him in the Colledge that day, when our School exhibited an Action in the Hall, and I met him after Supper; now in this Action I had both acted and ſung, and they came and congratulated me for my ſinging; Mr. Oates ſaid, if I had paid for learning to ſing, I had been baſely cheated; and then in the morning I was choſen Reader in the Sodality, the 25th of April, or thereabouts, for a fortnight, and Mr. Oates by his own ſubmiſſion was admitted to Read, only with this condition, that if ever he were wanting, I was to Read again; but this I ſay, I never ſupplied the place; theref • re I am ſure he did continue there all the while, and if he had been out, I muſt have been called upon to Read.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Were you in the Colledge all the time he was there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Beeſton.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I was.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did you miſs him at any time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Beeſtone.
sp.p: No, I never miſs'd him.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Are you ſure he was not away all that time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Beeſton.
sp.p: I am ſure, as much as a man can be certain of one that is of the ſame family with himſelf; nay, I am as ſure of it, as that I was there my ſelf.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Can you ſpeak any thing particularly of his Reading?

sp.speaker: Mr. Beeſton.
sp.p:
My Lord, I was to have Read, if he was abſent, but I was never called
upon to Read, and therefore I may well conclude he was there all the while.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He gives a material Evidence.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Was Mr. Oates ſuch a remarkable man that he muſt be miſs'd?

sp.speaker: Mr. Beeſton.
sp.p: He was very particular both for Age, and that he had a particular Table to Eat at.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Can you remember any thing elſe?

sp.speaker: Mr. Beeſton.
sp.p: I remember too, that when Mr. Bournaby came firſt, he was often with him the ſecond, third, and fourth of May, I ſaw him there with Mr. Bournaby, and I took particular notice of the friendſhip between them, which I thought ſtrange between perſons that I ſuppoſed never ſaw one another before.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Have you any Queſtions to ask this man, Mr. Oates?

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire to ask this Gentleman what Religion he is of.

sp.speaker: Mr. Beeſton.
sp.p: I am a Roman Catholick.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray my Lord be pleaſed to ask him, when he went to St. Omers, and when he came away thence, and how long he was Reſident there.

sp.speaker: Mr. Beeſton.
sp.p: I know not exactly what year it was I came, but I ſtayed the greateſt part of ſeven years there.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray my Lord ask him, what Jeſuits went from St. Omers to the Conſult of April 78.

sp.speaker: Mr. Beeſton.
sp.p: There was ſome that paſt by, I did not take much notice of them.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray my Lord ask him, who it was that informed him of that Conſult.

sp.speaker: Mr. Beeſton.
sp.p: I do not know who particularly, I only heard of ſuch a Rumour.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Was it an extraordinary thing?

sp.speaker: Mr. Beeſton.
sp.p: No, It was but an ordinary thing as they uſed to have once in three years.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: You ſay you ſaw me every day there.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He ſays he believes he might, becauſe you were Reader in his ſtead, and if you had been abſent, he muſt have been called upon to Read, which he was not, he ſays.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Very well my Lord, I deſire you would ask him, whether he does not remember ſuch a thing as an eight days Exerciſe, wherein thoſe that perform the Exerciſe, are ſeparated from all company during that time.

sp.speaker: Mr. Beeſton.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I do remember that he was once in that eight days Exerciſe, and during the eight days I ſaw him walk in the Garden ſeveral times.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray my Lord, ask him if he were an Evidence at the Tryal of the Five Jeſuits, or Langhorn, and whether he gave this Evidence long ago.

sp.speaker: Mr. Beeſton.
sp.p: No, I did not, I was not there.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray my Lord, ask him what Rewards he is to have.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Are you to have any Reward for your Teſtimony, Mr. Beeſton?

sp.speaker: Mr. Beeſton.
sp.p: No, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire to know of him, how he comes to be pickt out among the reſt of the Students there, to come here, and be an Evidence in this Cauſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Beeſton.
sp.p: My Lord, I was ſubpoena'd by His Majeſty, if I knew any thing of this matter, that I ſhould come here and teſtifie my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray by what name did he go by at St. Omers?

sp.speaker: Mr. Beeſton.
sp.p: By the name of Beeſton, as I do now.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: And is that his own name?

sp.speaker: Mr. Beeſton.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Pray go on Mr. Attorney.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Swear Clement Smith, (which was done.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Pray Sir, were you at St. Omers in the year 77 and 78?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: Yes, I was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Do you remember Mr. Oates there at that time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: Yes, I was in the ſame Claſs with him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray when came he thither, and how long did he ſtay there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: He came a little before Chriſtmas, and ſtayed till June.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Was he not abſent at any time all that while?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: No, he was not, except one day.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Do you remember Watton's buſineſs, his going thither in January?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: He told me of it, and that he deſign'd to ask the Rector leave to go.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was he abſent any other time till June?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p:
No, my Lord, for I will tell you, I every day Dined with him, eat
a Collation with him in the Afternoon, and Breakfaſt and Supp'd in the ſame Refectory, during all that time, except when he or I was in the Infirmary.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When ever he was abſent, he was in the Infirmary, was he?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did not he miſs his Breakfaſt at any time all that while?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: If he did, we us'd to enquire after him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray when were you in the Infirmary?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: The 21th of April New Style, I fell ſick, and I remained ſick till May the 7th, and was in the Infirmary, and then he viſited me almoſt daily, or every other day in the Infirmary; and on the 2d of May I ſaw him and one Mr. Bournaby together, and on the day Mr. Poole departed, which I take to be the fifth of May; Mr. Oates came to me as ſoon as he was gone out of the Houſe, and told me of it; and he did the ſame too that day that Mr. Hilſley went away, which was the 24th of April New Style.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Was not he in the Infirmary himſelf?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: Yes, during this time he came into the Infirmary, and was ſick there.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: When was that?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: A day or two after Mr. Hilſley went away, and continued there two or three days, and I remember it particularly by this circumſtance, that he propoſed a queſtion to the Phyſician about himſelf in Latine, and ſpoke a Solleciſm, which was this, he ſaid, Si placet Dominatio veſtra.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Who did ſay ſo?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You did, he ſays, ſpeak that falſe Latine to the Doctor.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: That's falſe Latine indeed.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: We know that, but it ſeems it was your Latine.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: When came he away from St. Omers?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: About the 20th of June, ſomething after the 20th of June, as I remember.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Are you ſure he was not out of the Colledge ſo long as to make a Journey to London, and back again?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: No, I am ſure he could not without being miſs'd; and going to School with him, and eating Dinner and Supper with him conſtantly alwaies at the ſame place, I muſt needs know if he had gone.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: When went I away from St. Omers does he ſay?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: After the 20th of June 78.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He is your old Acquaintance and Schoolfellow, Mr. Oates; you viſited him when he was ſick.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: What Religion is this Gentleman of, my Lord, I would know?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: I am a Roman Catholick.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: I deſire your Lordſhip to ask him how long he liv'd at St. Omers?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: Above ſix years.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray ask him, when he came away.

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: A little after Dr. Oates came away.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Did he come directly for England?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: No, I did not.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Whither did he go then?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: I went about a little.—

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Where, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: I went about to take ſome Turns in the Low-Countrys; I went to Watton, and up and down.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: He is a Jeſuit my Lord, and that the World knows, and muſt know.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I know nothing of it, I do aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Oates
sp.p: Pray my Lord be pleaſed to ask him, whether he did not hear of a Conſult of Jeſuits in April 78. and what Jeſuits went from St. Omers to it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: I heard it as a Rumour in the Colledge, that there was to be a Congregation at that time, but I know not where particularly it was to be kept; but I know that then there paſs'd by St. Omers two Fathers, Mr. Marſh, and Mr. Williams.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: What were they?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: Jeſuits.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He told you they were Fathers.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray was it an extraordinary, or an ordinary Meeting that?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: They us'd to ſay in the Colledge, that it was an ordinary thing to have ſuch a Congregation every three years.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Pray ſwear Mr. Edward Price, (which was done.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray Mr. Price will you give my Lord and the Gentlemen of the Jury an account whether you were at St. Omers in the year 77, and 78.

sp.speaker: Mr. Price.
sp.p: I was there both theſe years.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Do you remember Mr. Oates there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Price.
sp.p: Yes my Lord, I do.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: When did he come? and when did he go away?

sp.speaker: Mr. Price.
sp.p: He came there about December 77. and he continued there till June 78.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Was he abſent from St. Omers at any time all that while?

sp.speaker: Mr. Price.
sp.p: Never, that I know of, but one night at Watton, when he came back the following day, and that was in January.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Do you remember particularly that he was there in April and May 78?

sp.speaker: Mr. Price.
sp.p: I remember Mr. Hilſley according to the forreign Style left St. Omers upon the 24th of April 78. I was told the following day that Mr. Oates went into the Infirmary, which was Monday the 25th, and ſtayed there a day or two, and upon Wedneſday the 27th I ſaw him going to Maſs; then upon the Sunday following, which was the firſt of May New Style, came Mr. Bournaby to St. Omers, and I ſaw him in Oates's company that day, and I ſaw him on Monday again the ſecond of May in his company; I ſaw him the third of May at the Table, which I particularly remember, becauſe it was the Feaſt of the Invention of the Holy Croſs; the fourth of May I have no Circumſtance to remember him by; but the fifth of May I ſaw him take his leave of Mr. Poole, and I likewiſe ſaw him the 10th or 11th of May at another of our Actions, wherein Mr. Watſon had a quarrel with him, and beat him; I ſhould have miſs'd him above any other man, becauſe he was ſo noted a man.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What was he noted for, for any thing elſe but his diſtinct place in the Refectory?

sp.speaker: Mr. Price.
sp.p: Yes, he was very abſurd, and alwaies quarrelling with the Students there.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do you remember him Read in the Sodality?

sp.speaker: Mr. Price.
sp.p: I was not of that Bench that he was of.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire to know what this Gentlemans Religion is.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What Religion are you of Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. Price.
sp.p: If your Lordſhip pleaſe to know, I am a Roman Catholick.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire to ask him when he went firſt to St. Omers, and when he came away.

sp.speaker: Mr. Price.
sp.p: I was ſix years at St. Omers; I was there a twelve month before Mr. Oates came thither, and came from thence about three years ago.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Did you come directly to England when you came away?

sp.speaker: Mr. Price.
sp.p: My Lord, I went to Leige to ſtudy Philoſophy, and I live now with my Father at home.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire to ask him whether he did not hear of a Conſult to be held in April 78.

sp.speaker: Mr. Price.
sp.p: I did hear there was a Congregation which was their uſual Triennial meeting, and particularly I remember about that time there came Mr. Williams, and Mr. Marſh, and it was reported that they were going to the Congregation.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: I deſire to ask him if he was not a Witneſs at the Tryal of the five Jeſuits, or at the Tryal of Langhorne.

sp.speaker: Mr. Price.
sp.p: No, I was not.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray what name did he go by at St. Omers?

sp.speaker: Mr. Price.
sp.p: By my own name, which is Edward Price.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Then ſwear the next, that is Mr. James Doddington.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray Sir were you at St. Omers in the year 77 and 78?

sp.speaker: Mr. Doddington.
sp.p: Yes Sir, I was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did you know that Gentleman Mr. Oates there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Doddington.
sp.p: I know him very well.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What time did he come to St. Omers, and how long did he ſtay there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Doddington.
sp.p: He came about Chriſtmas, and ſtayed about the latter end of June.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: How do you remember he ſtayed there ſo long, what Circumſtances have you to make you remember it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Doddington.
sp.p: In general his Converſation and Canting Stories after Dinner and Supper, and times of Recreation, made him ſo remarkable, that no body could miſs him all the time he was there.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did you obſerve him to be in the Hall, or at the Exerciſes?

sp.speaker: Mr. Doddington.
sp.p: Yes, I ſaw him ſeveral times.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Do you remember the time Mr. Hilſley went away?

sp.speaker: Mr. Doddington.
sp.p: Yes, it was a little after Eaſter, and I do remember that two or three days after I went into the Infirmary, and ſaw Mr. Oates there, and had diſcourſes with him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Do you remember Mr. Bournaby's coming to St. Omers, and when was it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Doddington.
sp.p: Yes, the firſt of May Mr. Bournaby came to St. Omers, and the next day I ſaw Oates with him, and for ten or twelve daies ſucceſſively they were in one anothers company, and then of a ſudden the Correſpondence broke off, but I know not upon what account.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was he Reader there as you remember?

sp.speaker: Mr. Doddington.
sp.p: I do remember he did Read in the Sodality.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When was that?

sp.speaker: Mr. Doddington.
sp.p: I remember he Read at Shrovetide.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Did you hear me Read there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Doddington.
sp.p: Yes that I did Sir.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Were you of the Sodality?

sp.speaker: Mr. Doddington.
sp.p: Yes, I was Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Do you remember the time when he came away from St. Omers?

sp.speaker: Mr. Doddington.
sp.p: It was about Midſummer, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Were you out of the Colledge your ſelf at any time when he was there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Doddington.
sp.p: No, I was not.

sp.speaker: L C. J.
sp.p: Come, I will ask you a plain Queſtion; Was he ſo long at any time out of the Colledge as to come to London and ſtay here two or three daies, and come back again?

sp.speaker: Mr. Doddington.
sp.p: My Lord, he was ſo Remarkable by his Stories and Ridiculous Actions, and falling out with every one of the Colledge, that if he had been abſent, we muſt needs have miſſed him.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did you miſs him at any time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Doddington.
sp.p: My Lord, I never miſs'd him but one day.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When was that?

sp.speaker: Mr. Doddington.
sp.p: They ſaid he was gone to Watton.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What time was that?

sp.speaker: Mr. Doddington.
sp.p: In January, about ſix weeks after he came firſt.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray my Lord, ask him what Religion he is of.

sp.speaker: Mr. Doddington.
sp.p: I am a Roman Catholick.

sp.speaker: Oats.
sp.p: And a Scholar of St. Omers.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Make your Remarks by and by.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray my Lord, ask him what Name he went by at St. Omers.

sp.speaker: Mr. Doddington.
sp.p: By the Name of Hollis, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray my Lord ask him, how long he was Reſident there.

sp.speaker: Mr. Doddington.
sp.p: Near upon five years.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray my Lord, ask him the occaſion of his coming over at firſt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Doddington.
sp.p: I had buſineſs in England, and I had a mind to ſee my Friends.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray my Lord, ask him whether he did not pretend at the five Jeſuits Tryal, that he came over upon the King's Proclamation, to call home thoſe that were in the Seminaries.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Were you at the Tryal of the five Jeſuits?

sp.speaker: Mr. Doddington.
sp.p: Yes, I was; but if I came over upon the King's Proclamation, what hurt is there in that?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: None at all, as I know of.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray my Lord, ask him whether he did return again to St. Omers or no.

sp.speaker: Mr. Doddington.
sp.p: My Lord, I paſs'd by St. Omers once, but I never ſtay'd a day in the Colledge ſince.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray my Lord be pleaſed to ask him, whether he ever heard of a Conſult of the Jeſuits in April 78.

sp.speaker: Mr. Doddington.
sp.p: I did hear of a Congregation.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Call it a Conſult or a Congregation, it is all one.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He ſays he did hear of it.

sp.speaker: Oats.
sp.p: Ask him by whom he did hear of it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Doddington.
sp.p: I ſaw the Provincial when he came back from England.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Who was that Provincial, what was his Name?

sp.speaker: Mr. Doddington.
sp.p: Mr. Whitebread.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Was not Mr. Whitebread a Reſident ſometimes at St. Omers?

sp.speaker: Mr. Doddington,
sp.p: Yes a while he was.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray was not that Houſe under his Government?

sp.speaker: Mr. Doddington.
sp.p: My Lord, I can give no account of that, but it is generally under the Government of the Rector of St. Omers.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſeys.
sp.p: Pray Sir, give me leave to ask you one Queſtion Mr. Oates ſpeaks of Mr. Whitebread; Pray how did Mr. Whitebread uſe Oates, when he came back from England?

sp.speaker: Mr. Doddington.
sp.p: I heard ſay, he did check him very ſeverely for his many miſcarriages.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He heard it, he ſays, but he does not know it of his own knowledge; that is no Evidence.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Pray ſwear Mr. William Gerrard, (which was done.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Were you at St. Omers, Mr. Gerrard, in the years 77. and 78?

sp.speaker: Mr. Gerrard.
sp.p: Yes, I was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did you know Mr. Oates there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Gerrard.
sp.p: Where is he Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: There he is in that corner, do you know him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Gerrard.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: When came he to St. Omers?

sp.speaker: Mr. Gerrard.
sp.p: He came to St. Omers in the year of our Lord 77. and he went away in June 78.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Was he there all the time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Gerrard.
sp.p: I never remembred to have miſs'd him, but only once when he went to Watton for a night.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: By what Tokens do you remember him at any time there in April or May?

sp.speaker: Mr. Gerrard.
sp.p: The ſecond of May we had a Play, and he was there then, and I remember the 26th of May he was confirmed, and ſo was I, it being St. Auguſtin's day, and in the Refectory he had a Table by himſelf, and I uſed alwaies at mealtimes to paſs by that Table and make a Bow to the Fathers above before I ſate down at Table; and I do not remember that ever he was abſent, and if he had, I ſhould ſurely have miſs'd him.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When was St. Auguſtin's day, that you ſay you and he were confirm'd?

sp.speaker: Mr. Gerrard.
sp.p: It was the 26th of May.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Do you remember him in April there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Gerrard.
sp.p: I cannot tell any particular circumſtance in April, but I do not remember to have miſs'd him at all in April.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: But you ſaw him there the ſecond of May, you ſay.

sp.speaker: Mr. Gerrard.
sp.p: Yes, I did ſo, and the 26th of May.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: The 26th of May Old Style, I was there my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Ay, but he ſays the 26th of May New Style.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: I was not there then, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He ſwears you were.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Pray between the ſecond and 27th of May New Style was he abſent from St. Omers at any time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Gerrard.
sp.p: I never remember to have miſs'd him at all in that time.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Do you remember Mr. Pool's and Mr. Hilſley's going away?

sp.speaker: Mr. Gerrard.
sp.p: I do remember Mr. Hilſley's and Mr. Pool's going away, but I cannot ſpeak particularly and exactly what time that was.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Is it uſual to have Scholars go away without being miſs'd?

sp.speaker: Mr. Gerrard.
sp.p: No, my Lord, and he had a particular place by himſelf.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray ask him, my Lord, how he came to know that I went away in June?

sp.speaker: Mr. Gerrard.
sp.p: We miſs'd him in his place then, and 'twas diſcourſed of all over the Town, that when the Provincial came, he was to be diſmiſs'd.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: I deſire to know what Religion this Gentleman is of.

sp.speaker: Mr. Gerrard.
sp.p: My Lord, I am a Roman Catholick.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray my Lord, ask him what Name he went by at St. Omers.

sp.speaker: Mr. Gerrard.
sp.p: By the Name of William Clovell.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray my Lord ask him, when he went to St. Omers, and how long he was Reſident there.

sp.speaker: Mr. Gerrard.
sp.p: I came there about two years before he came, and was there about two years after he went away.

sp.speaker: Oats.
sp.p: Pray my Lord ask him, whether he came directly for England when he left St. Omers.

sp.speaker: Mr. Gerrard.
sp.p: No, my Lord, I was four years in Low Germany and France, and came into England the laſt year.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray Sir, were you a Witneſs at the five Jeſuits Tryal, or at Langhorns Tryal?

sp.speaker: Mr. Gerrard.
sp.p: No, I was not; I came but laſt year to England, I tell you.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray my Lord ask this Gentleman, whether he did not know or hear of a Conſult of Jeſuits that was to be in April 78. and from whom he heard it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Gerrard.
sp.p: My Lord, I know it is the Cuſtom of the Fathers of that Order to have a Congregation once in three years, about the Affairs of their Society, but then no Perſon is admitted to be one of that Congregation, but them that have been eighteen years Jeſuits, and he not having been ſo much as a Novice, I know not how, if he had been here, he could have been preſent at it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He ſays, that there us'd to be a Triennial Congregation for the Buſineſs of the Society, but you could not be preſent at it, becauſe you had not been eighteen years a Jeſuit.

sp.speaker: Mr. Gerrard.
sp.p: An. decimo octavo Currente, is the word of the Rule.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray my Lord ask him this Queſtion, how he knows that to be the Rule.

sp.speaker: Mr. Gerrard.
sp.p: You or any man may Read them in their Books.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: It ſeems he has Read them, and he ſays, you muſt paſs through eighteen years before you be admitted of the Congregation, and he believes you were not there, for you were not capable of ſo much as a Noviceſhip.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: I deſire your Lordſhip to ask him, whether or no he heard me Read in the Sodality.

sp.speaker: Mr. Gerrard.
sp.p: Yes, I did.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Were you of the Sodality?

sp.speaker: Mr. Gerrard.
sp.p: Yes, I was.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray my Lord ask him, what Oaths are there taken before they be admitted into the Sodality.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: No, by no means, I will not do it.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Why my Lord, may not I ask it, to ſhew what kind of men theſe are?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: No indeed, it is but the ſame Queſtion again, that I told you before is not to be asked, for it may make him liable to a Penalty; if you come to be a Witneſs, no man ſhould ask you a Queſtion that might make you obnoxious to a Penalty, no more muſt you ask them any ſuch Queſtions.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: I have done with him my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Where is my Lord Gerrard of Bromeley?

sp.speaker: Lord Gerrard.
sp.p: Here I am Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray my Lord, do you remember Mr. Oates at St. Omers in the year 77. and 78?

sp.speaker: Lord Gerrard.
sp.p: He was diſguiſed in another Habit, and another colour'd Perriwig, the Hair was blacker than that he has on now, but I remember his Face very well, and know him again by the Tone of his Voice, which was very remarkable, but I never remember that he was abſent from St. Omers after he came thither. I remember his coming exactly, which was about Chriſtmas; nor did I ever hear that he was abſent till June 78. New Style, when he went away.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Do you remember, my Lord, when Mr. Bournaby came?

sp.speaker: Lord Gerrard.
sp.p: I do remember Mr. Bournaby's coming, but what time it was I cannot exactly tell.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Is my Lord Gerrard ſworn?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: I think ſo.

sp.speaker: Lord Gerrard.
sp.p: No, my Lord, I am not ſworn.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You muſt be ſworn my Lord (which was done) now if you be pleaſed to ask my Lord any Queſtions, do.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, we deſire to know of my Lord Gerrard of Bromeley, whether he knew Mr. Oates at St. Omers.

sp.speaker: Lord Gerrard.
sp.p: My Lord, I remember he came in 77. as I take it, it was the beginning of December, and never heard he was abſent or miſs'd till June 78. I remember particularly upon the 25th of March, there was a new Lector to be Reader of the Sodality, and Mr. Oates deſiring it, he was appointed to Read; I was there my ſelf, and I never miſs'd him; I heard him Read, that I do remember ſeveral Sundays and Holidays, and never knew him abſent any one; however, for five or ſix weeks he was conſtant at Reading, and I can the better remember it, becauſe he had a particular Cant in his Tone, which all men may know, which ever converſed with him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: If Oates pleaſe to ask my Lord Gerrard any Queſtions, he may.

sp.speaker: Lord Gerrard.
sp.p: Pray my Lord let me ſpeak a word or two more.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Ay my Lord, pray go on.

sp.speaker: Lord Gerrard.
sp.p: I remember I heard Mr. Oates was at the Confirmation which was upon St. Auſtins day, there was a Confirmation by a Catholick Biſhop about the 26 of May New Style, I Remember I heard Mr. Oates was there, and the Biſhop did particularly note him as a perſon of elder years than the reſt of the Students.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do you know this my Lord, of your own knowledge?

sp.speaker: Lord Gerrard.
sp.p: I do my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Becauſe you ſay you heard it.

sp.speaker: Lord Gerrard.
sp.p: My Lord further I remember this, when the News of the Plot being diſcovered by Oates, came to St. Omers, where he went by the name of Sampſon Lucy, and ſometimes Titus Ambroſius, it was wondered by all the Scholars that knew him there, how he came to be ſo impudent to pretend that he was at ſuch a Conſult the 24th of April. 78. when all the Colledge ſaw him every day in April and May at St. Omers, as much as a man can be ſeen in a Family, and was never known to be abſent ſo much as one day; beſides my Lord, 'tis a thing as generally noted as a thing can be, that no Scholar goes away from, or comes to the Colledge of St. Omers, but it is particularly known to the whole houſe; It is the Common News and Diſcourſe as much as any new occurrences is here about the Town.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: If Oates be pleaſed to ask him any queſtions, he may.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire this Noble Lord may be ask'd a queſtion or two; I do not Remember his Lordſhip there.

sp.speaker: Lord Gerrard.
sp.p: I do very well remember the man by particular Remarques.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Yes my Lord, you have occaſion to remember me, and ſo have your whole Party. Pray my Lord let my Lord Gerrard be ask'd what name his Lordſhip went by at St. Omers.

sp.speaker: Lord Gerrard.
sp.p: Mr. Oates. I am not difficult in telling the name I went by there. It was Clovel.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray my Lord I deſire to know what Religion his Lordſhip is of.

sp.speaker: Lord Gerrard.
sp.p: Neither am I aſham'd to own my Religion. Mr. Oates. I am a Catholick.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray my Lord, If you pleaſe, becauſe this Noble Lord pretends he heard me Read, I deſire to know of him whether he was of the Sodality.

sp.speaker: Lord Gerrard.
sp.p: I remember you particularly by your voice, and that is one thing that particularly brings you to my Remembrance now.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray ask this Noble Lord if he was a witneſs at the Jeſuites Tryal.

sp.speaker: Lord. Gerrard.
sp.p: No, I was never a witneſs in my Life before; By the oath that I have taken.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: 'Tis very well my Lord.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray my Lord ask this Nobleman, whether he did not know of a Conſult in April 78. and from whom he knew it.

sp.speaker: Lord Gerrard.
sp.p: No, I know of none, nor heard of any but by Rumour after that you pretended to diſcover ſuch a thing.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Did his Lordſhip ſee me every day, does he ſay.

sp.speaker: Lord Gerrard.
sp.p: I cannot ſay every day, but I ſaw him at the Refectory generally, and I remember it particularly, becauſe he ſat at a Table by himſelf; I believe he could not be abſent without being miſs'd, becauſe we knew every perſon that came in and went out.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Then Swear Mr. Samuel Morgan (which was done.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Mr. Morgan were you at St. Omers in 77 and 78?

sp.speaker: Mr. Morgan.
sp.p: I was my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did you obſerve Mr. Oates to be there at that time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Morgan.
sp.p: Yes I did.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray give an account when he came, and when he went away.

sp.speaker: Mr. Morgan.
sp.p: He came 14 or 15 daies before Chriſtmas as I Remember, and went away in June.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What Chriſtmas do you mean, Mr. Morgan?

sp.speaker: Mr. Morgan.
sp.p: Chriſtmas 77.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: And when did he go away?

sp.speaker: Mr. Morgan.
sp.p: In June 78. he went away.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Was he abſent any time during that ſpace?

sp.speaker: Mr. Morgan.
sp.p: My Lord, I know not that he was ever abſent above one night in all that time.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What time was that one night?

sp.speaker: Mr. Morgan.
sp.p: Truly my Lord I cannot tell what month it was very exactly.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Whither was he gone that night?

sp.speaker: Mr. Morgan.
sp.p: He went to Watton, three miles off from St. Omers.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Do you remember the time when Mr. Hilſley came away, and when Mr. Bournaby came to St. Omers?

sp.speaker: Mr. Morgan.
sp.p: Yes, I do my Lord, very well.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Was Mr. Oates there when Hilſley went away?

sp.speaker: Mr. Morgan.
sp.p: He was there then.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Was he there when Mr. Bournaby came?

sp.speaker: Mr. Morgan.
sp.p: He was there when Mr. Bournaby came thither.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Was he there when Mr. Poole came away?

sp.speaker: Mr. Morgan.
sp.p: Yes my Lord he was ſo.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: I will ask you this ſhort queſtion, do you believe in your Conſcience that he was abſent any particular time all that while?

sp.speaker: Mr. Morgan.
sp.p: No my Lord, I have no reaſon to believe ſo.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray my Lord ask him what Religion he is of.

sp.speaker: Mr. Morgan.
sp.p: I am of the Church of England.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: When were you reconciled to the Church of England?

sp.speaker: Mr. Morgan.
sp.p: Five years ſince.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: I deſire to know of him, what induc'd him to be reconciled to the Church of England.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: That is not a pertinent queſtion, nor fit to be asked. Is he to give an account of his faith here?

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſtice Withens.
sp.p: It ſeems Mr. Oates is angry when the witneſſes are Papiſts, and when they are Proteſtants too.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: When was it that I came to St Omers do you ſay?

sp.speaker: Mr. Morgan.
sp.p: You came thither in December 77.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: So he told you before, why do you repeat things over and over again?

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: When was it I went away from thence ſay you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Morgan.
sp.p: In June 78.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Do you remember 24th of April Old Style that year?

sp.speaker: Mr. Morgan.
sp.p: Yes my Lord, I do remember it very well.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Do you remember him to be at St. Omers that day?

sp.speaker: Mr. Morgan.
sp.p: Yes, I do, by this circumſtance.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Ay, pray tell my Lord and the Jury that circumſtance, how you come to remember it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Morgan.
sp.p: We had the Tryal of Ireland brought over to us ſoon after it was Printed, and there we found mention'd that Mr. Oates had depoſed that the 24th of April 78. there was a Conſult of the Jeſuits, and they met at the White Horſe Tavern, where they reſolved to kill the King, and he carried that Reſolution from Chamber to Chamber, and he did nominate the day, and having it then freſh in my memory, though he ſwore that he was the 24th of April Old Style in London at that Conſult, yet I found him to be at St. Omers by a very particular circumſtance: My Lord, I was playing at Ball that day, and ſtruck it over into a Court, into which I could not get over my ſelf, but I ſaw Mr. Oates then walking in the Court, and I came and borrowed his Key, and ſo went in, and there paſſed between us words of friendſhip.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When was this, do you ſay?

sp.speaker: Mr. Morgan.
sp.p: The 24th of April 78. Old Style.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: I deſire to let his Orders be ſeen.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: No, he ſhall not be put to ſhew any ſuch thing.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: He is a Miniſter of the Church of England, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Sir, we tell you we will not do it, what ado is here with your impertinent Queſtions, have not I told you you ſhall not enſnare the Witneſſes?

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: He was a going to pull out his Orders himſelf.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, Mr. Oates may ſee them if he will, he is a Benefic'd Miniſter of the Church of England.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Does he mean thoſe Orders?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Yes, he does, and here they are.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Let him ſee them, (which was done.)

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire to know of this Gentleman, what Name he went by at St. Omers.

sp.speaker: Mr. Morgan.
sp.p: By the name of Morgan.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Swear Mr. Arundel, (which was done.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray Sir, will you give an account in ſhort whether you were at St. Omers in 77. and 78. and the time when Oates came thither, and when he went away.

sp.speaker: Mr. Arundel.
sp.p: I was there when Dr. Oates came, and when he went away.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: When was that?

sp.speaker: Mr. Arundel.
sp.p: Sir, I cannot be poſitive to the time exactly, but I think it was about January 77. that he came there, and he went away about June 78. I cannot be poſitive to the time exactly.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He does not particularly remember the time, but he thinks it was about January 77. he came thither.

sp.speaker: Mr. Arundel.
sp.p: I beg your Lordſhip pardon, he came there about December.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Do you remember any particular circumſtances that you ſaw him there at any particular time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Arundel.
sp.p: Upon St. Auguſtines day I ſaw him Confirm'd.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: What day is that?

sp.speaker: Mr. Arundel.
sp.p: The 26th of May according to the Forreign Account.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did you know him there then?

sp.speaker: Mr. Arundel.
sp.p: Yes my Lord, I ſay I ſaw him Confirm'd.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Do you remember Mr. Hilſley's going away?

sp.speaker: Mr. Arundel.
sp.p: I do not remember the time particularly, but I do remember Mr. Oates was actually there then.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Do you remember when Mr. Bournaby came to St. Omers?

sp.speaker: Mr. Arundel.
sp.p: No, I do not remember the time, but he was there then too.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Do you remember when Mr. Poole went away?

sp.speaker: Mr. Arundel.
sp.p: No, I cannot tell what day it was, but he was there at the time of his going away, upon my Oath.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Can you tell any other particular time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Arundel.
sp.p: The 11th of May New Style there was an Action exhibited in the Colledge.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was Oates there then?

sp.speaker: Mr. Arundel.
sp.p: To the beſt of my remembrance he was.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He does not affirm any particular, but only ſpeaks in general.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Are you a Proteſtant too Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. Arundel.
sp.p: No, Doctor, I am not.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray my Lord, I deſire to know what Religion he is of.

sp.speaker: Mr. Arundel.
sp.p: I am a Papiſt my Lord.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray ask him by what Name he went at St. Omers.

sp.speaker: Mr. Arundel.
sp.p: I believe you know that as well as I Doctor Oates.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You muſt anſwer his Queſtion.

sp.speaker: Mr. Arundel.
sp.p: I went by the Name of Spencer my Lord.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: I do remember him my Lord, to have been there.

sp.speaker: Mr. Arundel.
sp.p: Sir, your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: It is almoſt ſeven years ago, my Lord, and I may not ſo well remember them as they do me, but I deſire to know when he went to St. Omers firſt, and how long he was there.

sp.speaker: Mr. Arundel.
sp.p: I was there ſeven years.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray my Lord, ask him whether he was of the Sodality.

sp.speaker: Mr. Arundel.
sp.p: Yes my Lord, I was.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was he Reader of the Sodality?

sp.speaker: Mr. Arundel.
sp.p: Yes my Lord, in my time he was Reader.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Then my Lord I deſire to ask him, whether ever he heard of a Conſult of the Jeſuits, that was to be held in England in April 78. and from whom he heard it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Arundel.
sp.p: Yes my Lord, I did hear in the Colledge of a Congregation.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Was that an extraordinary one, or of courſe?

sp.speaker: Mr. Arundel.
sp.p: It was only of courſe, as they told us, once in three years they have one.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray my Lord be pleaſed to ask this Gentleman what Studies he followed at St. Omers.

sp.speaker: L. C. J
sp.p: He was of the Sodality, he ſays.

sp.speaker: Mr. Arundel.
sp.p: My Lord, I ſtudied to the end of Rhetorick.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire to know whether when he came from St. Omers, he did come directly for England.

sp.speaker: Mr. Arundel.
sp.p: No, I went from thence to Paris, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Swear Mr Chriſtopher Turbervile, (which was done.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray Mr. Turbervile, will you acquaint my Lord and the Jury whether you were with Mr. Oates at St. Omers, and when.

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervile.
sp.p: Yes my Lord; he went by the Name of Sampſon Lucy there, and there I ſaw him, and there I was with him all the time; I was there before him, and I remained there after he went away.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What time did he come to St. Omers, I pray you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervile.
sp.p: Before Chriſtmas.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: In what year?

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervile.
sp.p: In the year 77.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen
sp.p: What time was it he went away?

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervile.
sp.p: In June 78.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Were you there all that while at St. Omers?

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervile.
sp.p: Yes, I was.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And to the beſt of your apprehenſion, you think he was there all that while.

sp.speaker: Mr Turbervile
sp.p: Yes, I do ſo my Lord

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Can you ſpeak of any particular daies you can remember?

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervile.
sp.p: Yes, I do remember him upon the 4th, 5th, and 6th of May, for two or three daies together; for my Lord, I do remember this circumſtance, Mr. Poole about that time went away, and that very day Mr. Poole went from the Colledge, I changed my Lodging, and went into his Lodging, and that day I ſaw Doctor Oates in the Chamber, and by the Chamber door.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did he continue in the Colledge from the time he came about Chriſtmas, to the time he went away in June?

sp.speaker: Mr Turbervile.
sp.p: Yes he did, all the while except it were one night in January when he went to Watton.

sp.speaker: L. C. J
sp.p: What time in June did he go away?

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervile.
sp.p: I am not poſitive, but I am morally ſure he went away the 23th of June, as near as I can remember.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: I was there in June, that is very well known.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What do you remember of his Reading in the Colledge?

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervile.
sp.p: I do remember he was Reader there on Sundays and Holidays for a great while; I cannot ſwear upon what Sunday he began, but he left off the Sunday before he went away.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: As near as you can remember, when did he begin to Read?

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervile.
sp.p: It was the beginning of April, or latter end of March, I cannot juſtly ſwear which it was

sp.speaker: Mr. Molloy.
sp.p: Did he Read on Holidays as well as Sundays?

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervile.
sp.p: Yes he did

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: I muſt ask this Gentleman one Queſtion, if your Lordſhip pleaſe, and that is this, what Name he went by at St. Omers.

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervile.
sp.p: I went there by the name of Farmer.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray you my Lord, ask him what Religion he is of.

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervile.
sp.p: It is a hard Queſtion to anſwer that.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Nay my Lord, I deſire to know what is his Religion.

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervile.
sp.p: I am my Lord, a Roman Catholick.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Ask him when he went to St Omers firſt, and how long he ſtayed there.

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervile.
sp.p: I was there ſeven years very near.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: I deſire to know whether he did come away directly to England when he came from St. Omers.

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervile.
sp.p: No, my Lord, I went into Italy.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray you my Lord, I deſire to know whether he did go to Rome.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What if he did, what then? that is not at all to the purpoſe, he went into Italy.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray my Lord, be pleaſed to ask him this Queſtion further, was he a Witneſs on the behalf of the five Jeſuits, or of Langhorne at their Tryals.

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervile.
sp.p: No, my Lord, I was not.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray my Lord be pleaſed to ask him then what Reward he has been promiſed, or is to have for giving this Evidence.

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervile.
sp.p: None at all, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray my Lord ask him, whether or no he heard of any Conſult of the Jeſuits in April 78 and from whom.

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervile.
sp.p: There was a Congregation, as I heard, but I do not remember that any of the Fathers went from the Colledge to it; ſeveral came by there, and lodged there as they went, and as they came back.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray my Lord ask him how he came here to be a Witneſs in this Cauſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervile.
sp.p: I was ſubpoena'd.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Who ſerv • d the Subpoena upon him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervile.
sp.p: The Managers; it was ſent to me by the King's Councel, I ſuppoſe; a man brought it to me.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter who brought it you, you were ſubpoena'd, that's enough.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Swear Mr. Anthony Turbervile, (which was done.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Were you at St. Omers in 77, and 78?

sp.speaker: Mr. A. Turbervile.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did you obſerve the Defendant Mr. Oates there at that time?

sp.speaker: Mr. A. Turbervile.
sp.p: Yes, I obſerv'd him all the while he was there.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: When did he come to St. Omers?

sp.speaker: Mr. A. Turbervile.
sp.p: In the year 77, about Chriſtmas.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: When went he away?

sp.speaker: Mr. A. Turbervile.
sp.p: A Gentleman who was formerly ſworn, (Mr. Thornton) and I were at Breakfaſt with him the ſelf-ſame time when he went away.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When was that?

sp.speaker: Mr. A. Turbervile.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe about the latter-end of June 78.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did you obſerve him to be there in April or May 78?

sp.speaker: Mr. A. Turbervile.
sp.p: He was not abſent above one night in January that I can remember from his firſt coming thither, for it was impoſſible he ſhould be abſent and not miſs'd, he ſitting at a diſtinct Table by himſelf, and his Converſation being ſo remarkable for a great many ridiculous actions, and a great many pretty jeſts that he us'd, ſo that he was like a ſilly perſon, as I may call him, that us'd to make ſport, and no body could be miſs'd ſo ſoon as he: And I ſaw a little Boy in the Colledge beat him up and down with a Foxes Tail. Indeed, my Lord, all his actions were very remarkable: I ſee him very much abuſive to perſons that liv'd with him in the Colledge; and Mr. Oates could not be a perſon of this note, but all the world muſt take notice of him, and all that knew him muſt miſs him, if he were away.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You hear him, Mr. Oates; he gives you a particular Character; he ſays you were a very notorious perſon in many inſtances.

sp.speaker: Mr. A. Turbervile.
sp.p: My Lord, I was a perſon then the youngeſt in the whole Company, and Mr. Oates being very abuſive to me, I did what became me to right my ſelf upon him.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, be pleas'd to ask this Gentleman what the Name was he went by at St. Omers?

sp.speaker: Mr. A. Turbervile.
sp.p: By my Grandmothers Name, which was Farmer.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do you remember the time when Mr. Hildeſley went away from St. Omers?

sp.speaker: Mr. A. Turbervile.
sp.p: He went away upon a Sunday. Mr. Oates remain'd afterwards there: I am poſitive I ſaw him ſeveral days after.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do you remember when Mr. Burnaby came thither?

sp.speaker: Mr. A. Turbervile.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord; and Mr. Oates was there then.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Will you ask him any queſtions? If you are not ready, I will ask him ſome for you. Come, what Religion are you of?

sp.speaker: Mr. A. Turbervile.
sp.p: I am a Roman Catholick, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L C. J.
sp.p: Well, and how long were you at St. Omers?

sp.speaker: Mr. A. Turbervile.
sp.p: Six years and upward, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When you came away from thence, did you come directly for England?

sp.speaker: Mr. A. Turbervile.
sp.p: I took a circumference round.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I do find my Defence is under a very great prejudice.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Why ſo? becauſe we won't let you ask impertinent queſtions, or ſuch as may render the Witneſſes obnoxious to a Penalty.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: No, my Lord, it is not fit they ſhould, for there is a Turn to be ſerv'd.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What do you mean by that? Ay, and a good Turn too, if theſe Witneſſes ſwear true: 'Tis to bring Truth to light, and perjur'd Villains to condign puniſhment.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Good my Lord be pleaſed to hear me.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: If you behave not your ſelf with that reſpect to the Court as you ought, pray get you gone. Do you think you ſhall give ſuch language as this in a Court of Juſtice?

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I did not deſign—

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: If you behave your ſelf as you ſhould, you ſhall have all due regard; but if you flie out into ſuch abuſive extravagancies, we'll calm you as you ought to be calm'd.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: I would vindicate my ſelf, I meant it not of the Court.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: So you had need. Don't think we ſit here to let you aſperſe the Juſtice of the Court and of the Nation, as if the Judges ſate here to ſerve a Turn.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: I ſay theſe men do come to ſerve a Turn; but I laid no aſperſion upon the Court, nor meant it of them.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Behave your ſelf as you ought, and you ſhall be heard with all the fairneſs can be deſir'd.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: I did perceive your Lordſhip and the Court made your ſelves pleaſant with my queſtions.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I did not make my ſelf pleaſant with your queſtions, but when you ask impertinent ones you muſt be corrected: You ſee we do the ſame thing with them; I find fault with nothing but what is not to the purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire it may be obſerv'd, that theſe men that come now, are the ſame Witneſſes that appeared at the Old-Bailey, and were not believed there.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Obſerve what you will by and by.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: No, they are other Men, but they bear the ſame Teſtimony indeed.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Swear Mr. Clavering, (which was done.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Come, Sir, I'll ask you a ſhort queſtion: Were you at St. Omers with Mr. Oates, and when?

sp.speaker: Mr. Clavering.
sp.p: Yes, I was: I came the 10th of December 77 to St. Omers, he told me he came thither that day too, and I liv'd there all the time that he was there, which was till towards the middle of Summer: I do not remember that he ever was abſent, but once at Watton.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Do you remember Mr. Burnaby's coming thither?

sp.speaker: Mr. Clavering.
sp.p: Mr. Oates was there when Mr. Burnaby came there.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Was he there when Pool came away?

sp.speaker: Mr. Clavering.
sp.p: He was there when Mr. Pool went away, and likewiſe I remember his being there at the time of the Congregation.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray tell the circumſtance how you know he was there then.

sp.speaker: Mr. Clavering.
sp.p: There came a Gentleman there that deſir'd a Charity of the Students, and I was the perſon that made the collection for him in the houſe; and I remember he did ask if there was any one that was a Student there that had been in Spain: We told him there was one, and deſcrib'd him, upon which he knew the Gentleman in Spain; upon that I told Mr. Oates that there was one there that knew him, but he deny'd to come and ſpeak with him. Now I remember that it was the time of the Congregation, for ſome enquiry made why he got ſo little money at Watton, and it was ſaid it was becauſe the Fathers were gone to the Congregation in England: And he ask'd me particularly, What was done at the Congregation in England?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did Oates ask that queſtion?

sp.speaker: Mr. Clavering.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, he did.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Whom did he ask it of?

sp.speaker: Mr. Clav.
sp.p: Of me.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When was that?

sp.speaker: Mr. Clavering.
sp.p: I think it was about the time of the Congregation.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How came he to enquire after it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Clavering.
sp.p: I was talking with him, and ſaid he to me, Know you nothing what the buſineſs is that they are to do at the Congregation? Said I, Mr. Lucy, I know not what they do; I think not much: for I hear at thoſe Meetings many times they ſtay an hour or two, and have done when they have choſen their Procurator.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: And you believe he was there all the time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Clavering.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I do believe it.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray my Lord let me ask him a queſtion or two.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Ay, what you will.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: What Religion is this Gentleman of?

sp.speaker: Mr. Clavering.
sp.p: I am a Catholick.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: A Roman Catholick you mean, I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Clavering.
sp.p: Yes, I always underſtood it ſo, Mr. Oates.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire to know how he came not to be produc'd at the Jeſuits Tryal, to give this Evidence he gives now.

sp.speaker: Mr. Clavering.
sp.p: I can give a very good reaſon perhaps: I was then, my Lord, in Germany.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: That's reaſon good enough of all conſcience.
