sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Withens.
sp.p: That was a new queſtion, and you have a ſatisfactory anſwer, I think.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Swear Mr. John Copley, (which was done.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Were you at St. Omers in 77 and 78?

sp.speaker: Mr. Copley.
sp.p: Yes, I was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Was Oates there then?

sp.speaker: Mr. Copley.
sp.p: I ſaw him all the time he was there.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: When did he come thither?

sp.speaker: Mr. Copley.
sp.p: He came a little before Chriſtmas, to the beſt of my remembrance.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: When went he away?

sp.speaker: Mr. Copley.
sp.p: In 78.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: In what month in 78?

sp.speaker: Mr. Copley.
sp.p: In June 78.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Was he abſent any part of that time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Copley.
sp.p: I was there, and he was there too.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Was he abſent any part of the time from Christmas to June?

sp.speaker: Mr. Copley.
sp.p: Nay, I am ſure he was there all the time, except that night that he was abſent at Watton, and that was in January.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray my Lord ask him what Religion he is of.

sp.speaker: Mr. Copley.
sp.p: Does your Lordſhip ask me that queſtion?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Yes, I do ask you, Mr. Oates would know it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Copley.
sp.p: I am a Roman Catholick, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Swear Mr. Cook, (which was done.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did you know Mr. Oates at St. Omers, and when?

sp.speaker: Mr. Cook.
sp.p: He came there a little before Chriſtmas 77.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: How came you to know him there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Cook.
sp.p: I liv'd in the Houſe then.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Was he there all April and May?

sp.speaker: Mr. Cook.
sp.p: Yes, he was till the latter-end of June.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did you ſee him every day?

sp.speaker: Mr. Cook.
sp.p: Yes, I did.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Can you tell any particular time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Cook.
sp.p: I am poſitive he was the 30th. of April.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What ſtile?

sp.speaker: Mr. Cook.
sp.p: New ſtile.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How do you know he was there then?

sp.speaker: Mr. Cook.
sp.p: It is a remarkable time; there is a Proceſſion that they keep there on that day from the Sodality to the Church, and I ſaw him go among the reſt at the latter-end among the Rhetoricians.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What ſay you, was he there on that day Mr. Hildeſley went away?

sp.speaker: Mr. Cook.
sp.p: I do not remember that.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do you remember Burnaby?

sp.speaker: Mr. Cook.
sp.p: I was there when Mr. Burnaby went away.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But when he came was Oates there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Cook.
sp.p: I cannot ſpeak particularly to that.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What was your place in the Colledg?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, he is a Lay-man be ſure.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cook.
sp.p: I was a Servant in the Houſe.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: In what place do you ſerve?

sp.speaker: Mr. Cook.
sp.p: I was a Tayler.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: I do not remember him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cook.
sp.p: But I remember you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Swear Jo. Wright Eſq (which was done.)

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Do you remember Oates at St. Omers?

sp.speaker: Mr. Wright.
sp.p: Yes, I do.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: When was it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Wright.
sp.p: The Winter before the notice of the Plot was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What year was it in?

sp.speaker: Mr. Wright.
sp.p: In the year 77.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What month in that year did he come thither?

sp.speaker: Mr. Wright.
sp.p: I cannot tell, it was Winter-time.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: When did he go away?

sp.speaker: Mr. Wright.
sp.p: He went away in Summer, I cannot tell juſt the time.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Was he abſent at any time, from his coming in Winter, to his going away in Summer.

sp.speaker: Mr. Wright.
sp.p: The Scholars ſaid he was once at a place call'd Watton.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Come, this ſays nothing to the purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, we leave it here.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What ſay you to it then Mr. Oates?

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Has Mr. Attorney done?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Yes, we have done for the preſent.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Then are you to make your defence.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, Here is an Indictment brought againſt me for Perjury; and this Indictment ſets forth, That I ſhould upon the 17th. of December appear at the Old-Bailey, and there ſwear, That there was a Treaſonable Conſult of the Jeſuits met at the White-horſe-Tavern in the Strand, and that this Treaſonable Conſult did divide it ſelf into leſſer Companies and Meetings, and that I carried about a certain Reſolution, which the Jeſuits came to, concerning killing the King, from Chamber to Chamber to be ſign'd. My Lord, I have a great exception to make to this Indictment, and that is, my Lord, as to the form▪ For, by your Lordſhips favour, I think the Perjury is not well aſſign'd, and according as I am adviſed I offer this to your Lordſhips conſideration. It ſays in the aſſignment of the Perjury, Ubi revera & in facto praedictus Titus Otes non praeſens fuit ad aliquam Conſultationem Jeſuitarum apud le White-horſe-Tavern praedict in le Strand in Com Midd' praedict' ſuper viceſimum quartum diem April' anno Dom' Milliceſimo.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How Milliceſimo!

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, it is Law-Latine, I ſuppoſe it may ſerve in a Court.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: No, it is true Latine there:

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: I cannot tell how to read it better.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I do believe that.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: It is written in ſuch a hand, I cannot read it; but the ſubſtance of it is, it ſays here, That I did not carry any Reſolution from Chamber to Chamber ſignand'. Now, the Evidence charged upon me to be given, is, That I did not ſee it ſignat': So that the aſſignment of the Perjury does not purſue the Oath as it is ſet forth; for if it be ſignat' in the Evidence that was given, it ought to be ſignat' in the Perjury that is aſſigned; and I humbly crave the Opinion of your Lordſhip and the Court upon this point.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Look you, Mr. Oates, That you offer'd before, and I gave this Anſwer, which I muſt now repeat, That now we are upon the Fact, and this exception will be ſav'd to you for its proper time, if you be convicted. It is not proper now; but ſuppoſe there were that thing which you ſay is an Objection, yet you muſt know that there are Two Perjuries that are aſſign'd; the One is upon the firſt part of your Oath, which was, That you were preſent at a Conſult of the Jeſuits the 24th. of April 78. at the White-horſe-Tavern in the Strand, Ubi revera you were not there. Now, Do you admit in the firſt place, that you were forſworn in that particular.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: No, my Lord, I do not.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: If the Jury find that you were forſworn in that firſt point, that you were not there, it will be eaſily believed you ſwore falſe in the other point, that you did not carry the Reſolution from Chamber to Chamber.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: But, my Lord, it is not well aſſign'd, I think.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: That will be ſav'd to you after the Verdict, I tell you, if there be occaſion for it.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I ſuppoſe the Proof ought to be according to the Record, and the Record makes the Perjury differ from the Oath.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I tell you that is to the form, and that will be ſav'd to you after the Verdict one way or the other.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Then will your Lordſhip be pleaſed to conſider there was a Record brought in, which is almoſt the ſame with that I am to offer to be read on my behalf, and which is the firſt Proof that I have to offer of the Conſult that was held in London in April 78. And I deſire Mr. Percivile may be called, I forget his Chriſtian-name, and Mr. Vaughan who is my Sollicitor: But pray, my Lord, let me firſt have the Opinion of the Court, whether they did prove the words that I am ſaid to ſwear as they are laid in the Indictment.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Yes, very fully, we think ſo; but the Jury are to try that, that is a point of Fact: but if you will, you ſhall have our thoughts about it; We think they are fully proved.

sp.speaker: Cryer.
sp.p: Here is Mr. Percivile.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray ſwear him, (which was done)

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What do you ask him?

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Mr. Percivile, you examin'd the Conviction of Mr. Ireland, pray put it in: Is it a true Copy?

sp.speaker: Percivile.
sp.p: Yes, it is.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire that the Conviction and Attainder of Mr. Ireland may be read.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: It has been read already.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I will not take up the Courts time any more than is neceſſary for my Defence.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Nay; do as you will, as long as you offer things pertinent and decent, the Court will hear you with all patience, and you may take what time is neceſſary for you.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: I thank your Lordſhip: I deſign'd nothing at all of reflection upon the Court, but a reflection on the Witneſſes that came in againſt me.

sp.speaker: C. of the Crown.
sp.p: This is a Copy of the ſame Record that was before read.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Well, if that be allowed for Evidence for me, I am contented to ſpare the time of the Court, not to read it again: but, my Lord, I offer this, and deſire to have Councel aſſign'd me to argue this point in Law; that is, Whether or no the Convictions and Attainders of Ireland, Whitebread, and the reſt of them, of a Treaſonable Conſult of the 24th. of April 78. where it was reſolv'd to murder the late King, ought not to be taken as a ſufficient Legal Proof of the Fact, ſo long as thoſe Attainders remain of force? and whether the averment of that being falſe, is to be received againſt thoſe Records.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: There is no difficulty in that at all in the world, Mr. Oates.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I do not know the Law, and therefore I pray I may have Councel aſſign'd to argue that point.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: There is no queſtion in it. God forbid, if a Verdict be obtain'd by Perjury, that that Verdict ſhould protect the perjur'd party from being proſecuted for his falſe Oath. There were no Juſtice in that; nor is it an averment againſt a Record, for this is not a Writ of Error in fact that will reverſe it, but the Record remains a good Record and unimpeached ſtill: But though it be a good Record, yet it is lawful to ſay this Verdict was obtain'd upon the Teſtimony of ſuch an one, that forſwore himſelf in that Teſtimony, and for that particular Perjury he may ſurely be proſecuted.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Is not that Attainder an uncontroulable Evidence of the Fact, 'till it be revers'd?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Yes, it is againſt the party attainted; but if that Attainder was founded upon a Verdict that was obtain'd by Perjury, God forbid, but he ſhould be told ſo that did perjure himſelf.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p:
Well, my Lord, if your Lordſhip rules that for Law, then I will go on; and I muſt now obſerve to the Jury in the opening the Evidence two things. Firſt, That the Indictment upon which Ireland was try'd, was found the 16th. of December 78, and on the 17th. of December, the next day, Ireland was try'd at the Old-Bailey; and then I find this Indictment brought againſt me for Perjury, is found at the Old-Bailey ſix years after the Fact by ſpecial Commiſſion. Now, I ſubmit it to your Lordſhips and the Juries conſideration, why the Preſentment and the finding of this Bill for Perjury has been ſo long delay'd, ſince it appears by the Evidence, that the Witneſſes that have been produc'd to prove the Perjury, were either at the Trial of the Five Jeſuits, or might have been produced then; and though they are not all the ſame perſons, yet they all bear the ſame Teſtimony that was then offered, but were not credited; and I hope when my Evidence is heard, they will have the ſame Reputation with this Jury that they had with thoſe others. My Lord, I muſt acquaint your Lordſhip and this Court, That in this Indictment for which Mr. Ireland was convicted, Mr. Whitebread and Mr. Fenwick did undergo part of the Tryal, and did hear the whole body of the Evidence that the Witneſſes teſtified againſt them; but there being but one Witneſs againſt them two at that time, which was my ſelf, (Mr. Bedloe being then upon an Intrigue, as your Lordſhip may remember) my Lord Chief Juſtice Scroggs, who was then the mouth of the Court, did diſcharge the Jury of Mr. Whitebread and Mr. Fenwick, and remanded them to Priſon, which Mr. Whitebread ſix months after did remark to the Court, and urg'd it as a Plea for himſelf to be diſcharg'd: but that being over-rul'd by the Court, he was try'd. Now,
he had ſix months time to provide himſelf with new freſh Evidence to aſperſe me, and to endeavour to falſifie that Teſtimony I gave in againſt Whitebread and Fenwick, when Ireland was try'd, and ſo he knew what it was. I muſt further obſerve to you, my Lord, and Gentlemen of the Jury, That my Caſe is very hard, that ſince the ſubſtance of my Teſtimony was with credit receiv'd, and the Jury upon convicting them were acquainted, That they had found an unexceptionable Verdict; That all the Objections againſt the Evidence were then fully anſwer'd; That there was nothing that the Priſoners had been wanting in to object, which could be objected; and that the thing was as clear as the Sun. And yet, after ſix years time, I muſt come to be called to an account for Perjury in my Teſtimony of that part of the Popiſh Plot, with which the King and Kingdom, four ſucceſſive Parliaments, all the Judges of the Land, and three Juries, were ſo well ſatisfied. I ſhall therefore offer to your Lordſhip and the Juries conſideration the unanimous Votes of three Houſes of Commons; I ſhall offer the Proceedings of the Houſe of Lords, that is the higheſt Judicature in the Kingdom; I ſhall prove what I have open'd by the Teſtimony of ſeveral Noblemen that are here, who will teſtifie this for me. My Lord, I ſhall prove, that ſeveral attempts have been made to baffle this Teſtimony, as that of the Murther of Sir Edmundbury Godfrey, who took my Depoſitions, the Contrivance of Paine, Farewell, and Thompſon, made in the year 81 or 82, I forget which; I ſhall then produce Evidence that I was actually here in Town at the time in queſtion; and then upon the whole I ſhall ſubmit it to your Lordſhip and the Jury. But to prepare your Lordſhip and the Jury the better for my Evidence, I would again urge the ſtrangeneſs of this Proſecution, and the hardſhip that is put upon me, to be tryed for Perjury in an Evidence given ſix years ago, and formerly very induſtriouſly, though not ſuccesfully, endeavoured to be falſified by ſixteen St. Omers Youths that were produced and examined before all the Judges in the Kingdom, and that not only once at Whitebread's Trial, but a ſecond time at Langhorn's Trial, in neither of which would the Jury believe them, becauſe of their Religion and Education, and the perſons under whom they were educated, who were men of known Artifice. Then, my Lord, I would this argue: If that time my Evidence were true, it muſt be true ſtill; for Truth is always the ſame; and if it were then true, and I can prove it to be true, 'twill be thought a hard thing without all doubt, that this ſhould be put upon me. Then, my Lord, I would fain know from my Proſecutors, Why this Indictment of Perjury has been deferred ſo long? Why theſe Witneſſes that come now to teſtifie this matter, and could then have been brought, did not come before, to juſtifie at the Trials of theſe perſons what they now ſay, which might have ſav'd their Lives, if true, and had been credited. Then I ſhall offer to your Lordſhip what I deſire You and the Jury would pleaſe to obſerve, That though the King's Councel are now againſt me, yet they are alſo againſt themſelves, for they were of Councel for the King in thoſe Caſes: particularly Mr. Sollicitor at Langhorn's Trial, Sir Robert Sawyer at Sir George Wakeman's Trial: They were of Councel before for the truth of my Teſtimony; they are now againſt it: I only mention that, and paſs it over. But this is not the firſt attempt that has been made to diſcredit the Teſtimony of the Popiſh Plot, as I told you before. Now, can it be ſuppoſed that the love and deſire of publick Juſtice can be the cauſe of this attempt to falſifie my Evidence after ſo many Trials, in which it has been credited and confirmed? Can any thing, my Lord, more plainly tend to deſtroy and ſubvert the methods of Juſtice, to frighten all Witneſſes from henceforth from ever appearing to diſcover any Conſpiracies? and does it not tend to expoſe and vilifie the known Underſtanding and Juſtice of the late King of ever Bleſſed Memory, to arraign the Wiſdom of His Privy-Council, His Great and Noble Peers, His Loyal Commons in three ſucceſſive Parliaments, His Twelve Judges, and all thoſe ſeveral Juries that were upon thoſe Trials? Had not thoſe Juries ſenſe? had they not honeſty? had they no conſciences? And the Judges before whom thoſe Conſpirators were try'd, were they men of no Juſtice, nor Honour, nor Integrity, nor Conſcience, nor Underſtanding? Shall thoſe Juries be ſaid to have drawn the innocent Blood of theſe men upon their own Heads and the Nation? as, if I were perjur'd, it muſt be innocent Blood that was ſhed upon it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: No, no, that goes a great deal too far, Mr. Oates: The Jury have no ſhare, nor the Judges neither, in that Blood which was ſhed by your Oath.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſtice Withens.
sp.p: No, That is your own moſt certainly, and not theirs.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: But this, I ſay, makes it moſt plain: The Evidence was then true, and I hope I ſhall make it as evidently plain 'tis as true now; and I do not queſtion, but upon the Evidence I ſhall now give, both Poſitive and Collateral, the Jury will believe me, and acquit me of this foul Accuſation. Pray my Lord be pleaſed to conſider, that when the Jury brought in Ireland guilty of the High-Treaſon of which he was accuſed and convicted him, Pickering, and Grove; ſays my Lord Chief Juſtice Scroggs (that then was) to them, Gentlemen, you have done like very good Subjects, and very good Chriſtians, that is, like very good Proteſtants; and now much good may do them with their Thirty Thouſand Maſſes; as I ſhall prove he did ſay. Then I inſiſt, in the ſecond place, That Whitebread's Conviction does reinforce the Conviction of Ireland, becauſe of the attempt by the St. Omers Witneſſes to have overthrown my Evidence: But ſince I am attaqu'd again in the ſame kind by the violence of the Popiſh Intereſt, and by the malice of my Popiſh Adverſaries, I am contented to ſtand the Teſt with all my heart. And then, to conclude all, I ſhall ſhew the Court, That 'tis in vain for the Popiſh Party to expect and think to wipe their mouths, with Solomon's Whore, and ſay they have done no wickedneſs: No, I queſtion not but thouſands of Proteſtants in this Kingdom are fully ſatisfied and convinced of the Truth of the Popiſh Plot, all and every part of it. Now, my Lord, if you pleaſe to give me leave to proceed on in my Evidence, I ſhall beg that theſe Records of Conviction may be read, which are my firſt Proof of the Conſult; and I ſhall then bring Witneſſes, viva voce, and ſhall make it appear, that what I did ſwear at thoſe Trials was true.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Not to intetrupt you in your Defence, or the method you will take for it, I would put you upon that which is proper for you to apply your ſelf to, becauſe the queſtion now is not, Whether there was a Conſult or Congregation of the Jeſuits here upon the 24th. of April 78? but the queſtion that toucheth you is, Whether you were preſent at any ſuch Conſult here in London the 24th. of April 78? Theſe Gentlemen, ſome of them, do ſay, there was a Conſult, and others that they heard of it, and believe there was ſuch an one, becauſe it was uſual to have a Triennal Congregation for ſome particular purpoſes: But the queſtion, is, Whether you have ſufficient proof to prove your ſelf to be here on the 24th. of April 78, at which time it is agreed of all hands there was a Conſult?

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: But will your Lordſhip be pleaſed to take notice of the drift of the Evidence, how they are conſiſtent one with another? Theſe Gentlemen that have now been ſworn to prove that I was not at this Conſult, do attempt to prove that I was at St. Omers: Now, to anſwer this, I ſhall not go about to prove that I was not then at St. Omers, but that I was actually then, and about that time, here in London; and then all that proof that Mr. Attorney-General has brought muſt be laid aſide.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You ſay well; prove that.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Now, my Lord, to introduce and prepare the Jury for this, it will be neceſſary, I humbly conceive, to read the Records of the Conviction of Whitebread and Ireland.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, go your own way. We are not to direct you: I only tell you where the queſtion lies.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Sir Samuel Aſtrey, pray be pleaſed to read them in Engliſh, that the Jury may underſtand them. Firſt read Ireland's Record, (which was done.)

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Now read Whitebread's Record: Read but the Attainder, I will not trouble the Court with the whole Record.

p.q: Thomas White, alias Whitebread, William Harcourt, alias Harriſon, John Fenwick, John Gaven, and Anthony Turner, were found guilty of High-Treaſon, and attainted, and Execution awarded againſt them upon that Attainder.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Does not the Record ſay, The Jurors ſay upon their Oaths they are guilty.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Yes, I'll warrant you.

sp.speaker: Cl. of the Crown.
sp.p: It is Dicunt ſuper ſacramentum ſuum.

sp.speaker: Oates,
sp.p:
Very well. Theſe, my Lord, I do produce as my firſt Evidence, to prove that there was a Trayterous Conſult held upon the 24th. of April 78, at the White-horſe-Tavern in the Strand, it having been believed and affirmed by two Verdicts. Now give me leave to offer but this to the Court, That at the Trial of Mr. Ireland I gave ſo
full and ample a Teſtimony againſt Whitebread and Fenwick, accompanied with all the circumſtances of Time and Place, that my Lord Chief Juſtice Scroggs ſaid, The Evidence might be ſufficient to have ſatisfied a private conſcience, though it was not a legal Proof then to convict him, there being but one Witneſs againſt them: And for this I call Mr. Robert Blayney.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray ſwear Mr. Blayney, (which was done.)

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What do you ask Mr. Blayney?

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Mr. Blayney, have you your Notes of Ireland's Trial here?

sp.speaker: Mr. Blayney.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I have.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray will you look into what my Lord Chief Juſtice Scroggs ſaid when he diſcharged the Jury of Whitebread and Fenwick.

sp.speaker: Mr. Blayney.
sp.p: Whereabouts is it, Sir, in the Printed Trial?

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: It is page 55.

sp.speaker: Mr. Blayney.
sp.p: I have found the place, what is it you would ask me about it?

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Whether my Lord Chief Juſtice Scroggs did not uſe theſe words to the Jury: I do acknowledge that Mr. Oates has given a very full and ample Teſtimony, accompanied with all the circumſtances of Time and Place, againſt them all; That may go far with you, all things conſidered, to believe there is a Plot: Yet I do not think they have proved it against Whitebread and Fenwick by Two Witneſſes, though the Teſtimony be ſo full as to ſatisfie a private conſcience, yet we muſt go according to Law too. It will be convenient from what is already proved, to have them ſtay till more proof come in; 'Tis a great Evidence that is againſt them, but it not being ſufficient in point of Law. We diſcharge you of them. It is not a legal Proof to convict them by, whatſoever it may be to ſatisfie your conſciences.

sp.speaker: Mr. Blayney.
sp.p: I have look'd upon my Notes, and I cannot find exactly thoſe words.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He ſays he cannot find that paſſage as it is there.

sp.speaker: Mr. Blayney.
sp.p: There is ſomething to that purpoſe, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, will you look into your Notes in the very ſame place, what my Lord Chief Baron ſaid: You muſt (ſpeaking to the Jayler) understand they are no way acquitted: the Evidence is ſo full againſt them by Mr. Oates's Teſtimony, that there is no reaſon to acquit them; it is as flat as by one Witneſs can be.

sp.speaker: Mr. Blayney.
sp.p: There is ſuch a paſſage, I find, in my Notes.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He ſays there is ſuch a paſſage.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Then I deſire Mr. Blayney would look into his Notes, what my Lord Chief Juſtice Scroggs ſaid in his ſumming up the Evidence againſt Ireland: He mentions the Evidence of Sir Dennis Aſhburnham, who was produced to diſcredit me, and then he adds, When the matter is ſo accompanied with ſo many other circumſtances, which are material things, and cannot be evaded or deny'd, it is almost impoſſible for any man either to make ſuch a ſtory, or not to believe it when it is told. — It is Ireland's Trial, page 72.

sp.speaker: Mr. Blayney.
sp.p: My Lord, I do find ſuch a paſſage in my Notes.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He ſays there is ſuch a paſſage in his Notes.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Then I would ask Mr. Blaney another queſtion at the bringing in the Verdict of the Jury againſt Ireland, Pickering, and Grove, my Lord Chief Juſtice Scroggs (that then was) had this expreſſion You have done, Gentlemen, like very good Subjects, and very good Chriſtians, that is to ſay, like very good Proteſtants; and now much good may their 30000 Maſſes do them.

sp.speaker: Blayney.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, there is in my Notes ſuch an expreſſion of my L. C. J. Scroggs.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray you, Mr. Blayney, have you Whitebread's Trial? the Trial of the Five Jeſuits I mean.

sp.speaker: Mr. Blayney.
sp.p: My Lord, when I received a Subpoena from Mr. Oates to be here this day, and to bring my Notes of Ireland, Whitebread and Langhorns Trials, I did (as I did before upon another occaſion) make a ſearch for all my Notes, but could not find any but thoſe of the Trial of Ireland and Langhorn, and thoſe I have brought here, but have not Whitebread's.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He ſays he has not the Notes of Whitebread's Trial; he cannot find them.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Then I muſt deſire, my Lord, that the Printed Trials may be read.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: No, they are no Evidence: If you can prove what was ſaid at any of them, you may by Witneſſes, but not by the Printed Books.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Then will your Lordſhip be pleaſed to give me leave to mention what was ſaid by your Lordſhip at that time, when you were Recorder of London, about your ſatisfaction with the Evidence?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Ay, with all my heart, and whatever I ſaid I will own, if I can remember it.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Will your Lordſhip be pleaſed to be ſworn then?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: No, there will be no need for that; I will acknowledge any thing I ſaid then.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Then, if your Lordſhip pleaſes, I will read thoſe paſſages out of the Books.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Ay, do ſo.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Says Mr. Recorder of London, (in particular to that part of the Priſoners Defence, at the Trial of the Five Jeſuits, and the full ſcope given them of making Objections to the Evidence) when he gave Judgment of Death upon theſe Five Jeſuits and Langhorn, (for I now ſpeak of your Lordſhip in the third perſon) Your ſeveral Crimes have been prov'd againſt you: you have been fully heard, and stand convicted of thoſe Crimes you have been indicted for.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I believe I might ſay ſomething to the ſame purpoſe as you have read now.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: I thank your Lordſhip for that acknowledgment.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Ay, I'll own any thing I did ſay.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I have one paſſage more to urge, and that was my Lord, after the Jeſuits had been convicted, when the Jury brought in their Verdict, and found Whitebread, Fenwick, Harcourt, Gaven, and Turner guilty, your Lordſhip applying your ſelf to the Jury, ſaid thus to them; Gentlemen, you of the Jury, there has been a long Evidence given againſt the Priſoners at the Bar; they were all indicted, arraigned, and tried for High-Treaſon depending upon ſeveral circumſtances? They can none of them ſay the Court refuſed to hear any thing they could ſay for themſelves, but upon a long Evidence, and a patient hearing of the Defence they made, they are found guilty, and for any thing appears to us it is a juſt Verdict you have given.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I believe I might ſay ſomething to that purpoſe too at that time; and no doubt the Jury did (as the Caſe then ſtood) find an unexceptionable Verdict.

sp.speaker: Oates.
Mr. Juſtice Withens.
sp.p: We are got into an endleſs Wood of ſayings of people, I know not where and when; and when all is done, 'tis to no purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, it is a part, and a great part of my Defence, to ſhew what credit has been given to the Evidence of the Popiſh Plot.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Ay, but what Councel ſays at the Bar, or what Judges ſay in the Court of their Opinion is no Evidence of a Fact, of which the Jury are Judges only.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, every Judge is upon his Oath, and delivers his Judgment according to his Oath.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Not as to the Fact, but only in points of Law, ſo as to tell the Jury what the Law is, if the Fact be ſo and ſo.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, it goes a great way with the Jury to have the Judges Opinion.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p:
Mr. Oates, deceive not your ſelf; all this you have inſiſted on hitherto, has not been to the purpoſe, nor is any ſort of Evidence in this caſe; and therefore do not run away with an opinion of this as Evidence: a Judges Opinion is of value in points of Law that ariſe upon Facts found by Juries, but are no Evidence of the Fact, for Judges only do preſume the Fact to be true, as it is ſound by the Jury; and therefore
ſay they, Out of that Fact ſo found, the point of Law ariſing is thus or thus. Then in Caſe, after a Jury has given a Verdict of the Fact, a Judges Opinion of the Fact, (which may be perhaps contrary to the Verdict) ſhould be an Evidence as to that Fact, that would be to overthrow and nullifie the Juries Verdict: No, that is not the Judges Province. Surely you would not have a Judges private Opinion, that Twelve men have found a Verdict againſt the Fact, to be an Evidence as to that Fact: No; but admit the Fact to be ſo or ſo, then the perſon convicted of the Fact ought to ſuffer ſo or ſo. And by the ſame reaſon as this, a Jury of honeſt Gentlemen here, when I tell them here is a plain Fact either to convict you or to acquit you upon this Indictment, are not bound to go by what I ſay in point of Fact, but they are to go according to their own Oaths, and according to the Evidence and Teſtimony of the Witneſſes: It is not my Opinion that is to weigh at all with them, whether you are Guilty of this Perjury, or are Innocent, but the Evidence that is given here in Court. Therefore what my Lord Chief Juſtice Scroggs ſaid at any of thoſe Trials, or what I ſaid, or any other perſon, that either was of Councel, or a Judge on the Bench, ſaid as our Opinions, is but our Opinions on the Fact as it occurred to our preſent apprehenſions, but is no Evidence nor binding to this Jury. I muſt tell you, there is no doubt but that thoſe Juries did every one of them believe the Evidence you gave, or they would not have convicted the Priſoners. Do you think they would have found a Verdict againſt their own belief, and being upon their Oaths to make true Deliverance between the King and the Priſoners, have perjured Themſelves to hang Others? If they had ſo done, they had committed Wilful Murther, and the worſt of Murthers too, being under colour of the Proceſs of Law; but yet all this is no Evidence. I do not diſcommend you for inſinuating theſe things as introductive and preparative to what Evidence you have to offer; but it is no Evidence one way or other. Alack-aday! how many times have we Cauſes here in Weſtminſter-hall, wherein we have Verdict againſt Verdict? and yet no imputation to either of the Juries, which might give different Verdicts upon different Grounds. There was a notable Caſe lately of my Lady. Ivies at this Bar: We all thought upon the firſt Trial, that ſhe had as good a Title to the Land as could be; all the Judges and the Councel went way (I believe) ſatisfied with the Juries Verdict for her: But when the Cauſe came to be heard again, we found all the Witneſſes to prove her Title, were guilty of notorious Porjury, and the ſame perſons which did believe before that ſhe was in the Right, and the Jury had done well, when they heard the ſecond Trial did believe ſhe was in the wrong, and accordingly the ſecond Jury found it ſo; and we believe that laſt Verdict to be good, without any reflection on the Credit of the Firſt Jury, becauſe the Evidence was as ſtrong on her ſide then, as it was afterwards againſt her. In theſe Caſes we give our Opinions always according to the preſent Teſtimony that is before us.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Then, my Lord, I offer this to your Conſideration, That thoſe men that were thus charged by me with High-Treaſon, were Prieſts and Jeſuits moſt of them, and particularly Mr. Ireland, in whoſe Trial I am ſaid to have committed this Perjury, and you ſhall find him to have been by others proved a Prieſt and a Jeſuit, and actually engaged in a Deſign againſt the Life of the King. If I then do prove that Ireland was engaged in a Deſign againſt the late Kings Life, and was a Prieſt and a Jeſuit, I deſire to know, Whether this be not a Collateral Evidence to render me of credit ſufficient, and ſupport my Teſtimony.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p:
By no means upon this Indictment. It's true it may give ſome credit to your Teſtimony, but is not of it ſelf ſufficient: Nay, I'll go a great way further than that; I will ſuppoſe that there was a Conſult of the Jeſuits upon the 24th. of April 78 at the White-horſe-Tavern in the Strand, where thoſe you ſay were preſent, were all preſent, Ireland, and Whitebread, and Pickering, Grove and Fenwick, were all there, and that they did there come to a Reſolution to deſtroy the late King: Suppoſe all this to be true, and yet you all this time are not innocent of the Fact imputed to you, becauſe you ſwore directly, That You were there at that Conſult too, which you were not, if theſe men ſwear true, for then you were at St. Omers at that time; and therefore give us ſome ſort of Teſtimony to ſatisfie us that you were here,
and then you will ſet all right again. If the Jeſuits and Prieſts did Plot, that is nothing to make your Evidence true, if you ſwore that which you did not know of your own knowledge.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Shall it be allow'd then that Ireland was a Jeſuit and a Papiſt?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: If it ſhould that will be to very little purpoſe for your Turn.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: There is the Evidence of a Record for it, my Lord; but if that be not ſufficient, I can call Witneſſes to prove it. Pray call Mr. Miles Prance, (which was done, but be did not appear.)

sp.speaker: Cryer
sp.p: He is not here.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: He was ſubpoena'd, my Lord, to come hither.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I can't help it, if he will not come; but I'll tell you, for methods ſake, not to preſcribe to you, but to tell you what I think may be more for your advantage than any of theſe Inferences that you are making: If you did call two or three Witneſſes to prove that you were in Town the 22d. 23d. or 24th. of April, it would be the beſt Defence you can make, and would give the beſt anſwer to all that is objected againſt you.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: I will do that (my Lord) then, and follow your directions.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do ſo, that is the beſt way.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Cryer, call Cicilia Mayo.

sp.speaker: Cryer.
sp.p: Here ſhe is.

sp.speaker: Oates
sp.p: Swear her, (which was done.)

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, what do you ask this Witneſs?

sp.speaker: Oates
sp.p: Pray Mrs. Mayo give my Lord and the Jury an account whether you did ſee me in London the latter-part of April or the beginning of May 78; for that is the queſtion now before the Court.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Ay, what ſay you? when did you ſee him in 78?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: My Lord, I ſaw him the latter-end of April: He came to Sir Richard Barker's Houſe, where I did then live, and afterwards he came again thither within a few days. By this circumſtance I remember it; Sir Richard Barker my Maſter was ſick all the month of April, and in the Countrey, only he came now and then home for a little while, and went again: Now Mr. Oates came there when he was abſent, and a young man that lived in the Houſe came to me, and told me, There was Mr. Oates in the ſtrangeſt diſguiſe that ever was. Says he, I think he is turn'd Quaker: No, ſaid I, he is no Quaker, for they wear no Perriwigs, and I rebuk'd the young Man for ſaying ſo. As for Mr. Oates, I never ſaw his face before that time that I know of.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How do you know that to be Mr. Oates then?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: The Family knew him, and they told me it was he: That is the Gentleman there. I ſpeak now nothing but that which I teſtified ſeven years ago, and it is all Truth, and nothing but the Truth.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Ay, no doubt of it, thou ſwear'ſt nothing but the Truth.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Maro.
sp.p: My Lord, he came three or four days afterwards again to the houſe, and then the young man came to me, and told me, That Parſon Oates was turn'd Jeſuit; and thereupon I ſaid to him, Good Lord! why doſt thou concern thy ſelf with him? canſt not let him alone? I lookt upon him, and ſaw him at that time: And when he came that time, he went to Sir Richard's Ladies Siſter, who is now in Wales, and coming to her, ſaid ſhe, Mr. Oates, I hear you are turn'd Jeſuit, and we can have no Society with you now: At laſt, he ſtay'd to Dinner with them, and ſtay'd moſt of the day there. Then he comes the latter-end of May; Whitſuntide was in May that year, and I know he came before Whitſuntide by this token; I ſpeak of the ſecond time of his coming: Our Cuſtom in the houſe was to Waſh and Scowr before the time, and I was ſending for a Woman to come and help to Waſh and Scowr, and then he was walking in the Garden, and the young man came and told me Oates was there: he came into the Pantry to me, Look, ſaid he, he is come again, and he is turn'd Jeſuit by his diſguiſe: Why Benjamin, ſaid I, what haſt thou to do with the man? canſt not let him alone?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What was the Name of that young Man you ſpeak of?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo:
sp.p: Truly, my Lord, he is dead, or he would have teſtified the ſame thing.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But what was his Name?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: Benjamin; I can't tell his other Name.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, go on.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: Said I to him, Why doſt thou ſcorn this man? Prithee get out of the Room, I am not able to hear it: So he walk'd the ſpace of an hour in the Garden.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Is Sir Richard Barker living?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, he is, but he is not well.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was he at home when Oates was there?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: No, my Lord, I think not.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who din'd with him, do you ſay, when he din'd there?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: My Ladies Siſter.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: What is her Name?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: Madam Thurrel.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: And who elſe?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo
sp.p: And her Sons.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: Where are they?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: They are both dead.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: And who elſe was there?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: One Doctor Cocket.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: He is in Wales too, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: 'Tis a great misfortune to have ſo many dead, or ſo far remote.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, ſix years time makes a great alteration in a Family.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: Was there any body elſe there?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: There were two of the Daughters, and they could all come and teſtifie the ſame thing.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: Where are they, and what is become of them? why are they not here?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: They are living in Lincolnſhire, my Lord, I think.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: What elſe have you more to ſay?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray Mrs. Mayo let me ask you a queſtion: What colour'd Cloaths had he on when you faw him firſt?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: He had a whitiſh Hat, and colour'd Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: What time of the day was it you ſaw him?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: In the morning.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: Did he go publickly?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: Yes, he went publickly.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Did he come often to the houſe?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: He was there frequently, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Then it ſeems he was ſo diſguis'd, that he could walk publickly in the ſtreets of London at Noon-day, and was frequently in the Family.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: Now tell me who was in the Family.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Mrs. Mayo,—

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: Pray give me leave to ask her the queſtion: Who was there at that time?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: Sir Richard Barker's Ladies Siſter, Madam Thurrel, and his two Daughters, and two of his Kinſmen, and two of the Servants, one is here a Witneſs now.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: Who is that that is a Witneſs now?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: One that belongs to Sir Richard Barker, and the other is now dead, & thoſe two Kinſmen are dead.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: What is become of the two Daughters, ſay you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: They are in Lincolnſhire, as I take it, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: When did you hear from them?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, it is half a year ago almoſt ſince Mr. Oates had notice of this Trial.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: Where is Sir Richard Barker himſelf?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: I was with Sir Richard Barker, and he purpoſed to have come hither; but being a crazy man, and ancient, it ſeems he could not, and deſir'd to be excus'd, for he had a bad night, and was not well; but he deſired that the Court ſhould know, if he were well he would be there.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Were you ſworn at a former Trial about this matter, Mrs. Mayo?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Do you remember what you ſwore then?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: The ſame I do now.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Then I ask you this queſtion, How long before Whitſuntide was it that you ſaw Mr. Oates at Sir Richard Barker's?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: A pretty while before, twice.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Mrs Mayo, I'll put you a fair queſtion, Whether or no it might not be a fortnight before Whitſuntide you think?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: The laſt time I ſaw you was a week before Whitſuntide.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: How can you tell it was but a week?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: 'Twas but a week, becauſe at that time I had ſent the Boy for the Woman to ſcowr and waſh there.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: Was that the laſt time you ſaw him?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: Yes: I ſaw him ſeveral times before, and it was all before Whitſuntide.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: How long before that was the firſt time that you ſaw him?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: He would be away for three or four days, and come again.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: But how long before the laſt time was the firſt time you ſaw him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: He came ſtill to and again.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: When was the time that you ſaw him next before the week before Whitſuntide, which, as you ſay, was the laſt time you ſaw him?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: I am not able to ſay that.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: Did you believe it was within the compaſs of a week before?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: To the beſt of my remembrance it was.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: When was the firſt time you ſaw him?

sp.speaker: Mrs Mayo.
sp.p: 'Twas in the beginning of May.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: You ſaid at firſt it was the latter-end of April.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, let me a little think; I am unwilling to be miſtaken, I would ſay nothing but the Truth.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: No, I would not have thee; but for Gods ſake let us have the Truth, that is that we look for.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: I ſay the Coach-man ſaw him there as well as I, and he can tell you better than I.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: But I ask you this queſtion poſitively, Was it in May or April?

sp.speaker: Mrs: Mayo:
sp.p: To the beſt of my remembrance it was the beginning of May:

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: Was it within a week of May?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: I believe it was, I cannot tell exactly to a day.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Was it ſo or not?

sp.speaker: Mrs: Mayo:
sp.p: I cannot be poſitive to a day; it is now ſix years time ſince I was firſt examin'd about it.

sp.speaker: Mr: Att: Gen:
sp.p: But you can remember what you ſwore then, can't you?

sp.speaker: Mrs: Mayo:
sp.p: I declare it I ſpeak not a ſyllable but I will aver to be true before the great God:

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen:
sp.p: Can you ſwear it was within the firſt ſeven days of May?

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſtice.
sp.p: You ſee, Mr. Sollicitor, ſhe ſays ſhe cannot,

sp.speaker: Mr. Att, Gen,
sp.p: Did not you ſay at that Trial, that you did never ſee his face till a week before Whitſuntide, or a little after?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo,
sp.p: I did ſwear the ſame that I do now, to the beſt of my remembrance, & that is the Truth,

sp.speaker: Mr, Att, Gen,
sp.p: But did you not ſwear ſo?

sp.speaker: Mrs, Mayo,
sp.p: I never ſaw him before that firſt time he came to Sir Richard Barker's, and after the laſt time that he came I ſaw him not till after the Plot was diſcovered,

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: How long was that after he had been at your Maſters horſe?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: It was a good while, I cannot tell how long.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: Was it within a month or two months?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: It was more, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: Where was Sir Richard Barker at that time?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo
sp.p: He was at Putney.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: Then he did not ſee him?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo
sp.p: Not then he did not

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice
sp.p: Did he afterwards?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: Yes, he did ſee him afterwards.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Justice.
sp.p: How long afterwards was it?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: I can't tell how long afterwards it was my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: About what time was it?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: After the Plot was diſcovered he was up and down in the Family.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: You never knew Mr. Oates before that time he came in a Diſguiſe, and you did not know him then, but as they told you it was he?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: No, I did not, but as they told me then; and this is the man, I'll ſwear it.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Call John Butler.

sp.speaker: Crier.
sp.p: Here is John Butler.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Swear him, (which was done.) My Lord, if you pleaſe I will propoſe my queſtions to your Lordſhip; and my firſt queſtion is this, I pray your Lordſhip would ask him, Whether he gave in any Evidence at the Five Jeſuits Trial, or Langhorn's Trial, about my being in Town in April or May 78?

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: Did you give any Evidence at the Five Jeſuits Trial?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Yes, I did.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: Did you give any Evidence at Langhorn's Trial?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I was a Witneſs there.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, it is ſo long ago, that ignorant people that come innocently without deſign, may not be ſo ready in their remembrance, as thoſe that conn'd their Leſton for ſo long time together.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: Well, well; what do you ask him next, Whether he will ſtand by that Evidence he gave then?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: That is all I have to ſay, my Lord: I did teſtifie the Truth then, and will abide by it.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: But he muſt give the ſame over again here, or it will ſignifie nothing.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, it is now ſix years ſince, and this queſtion was not thought to be ſtirr'd ſo long after: Therefore I beg ſo much favour, that the Evidence he did give at Mr. Langhorn's Trial may be read to him.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: O by no means.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, it is ſuch a diſtance of time—

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: Look ye, if he has any Notes himſelf, he may look on them to refreſh him.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, he comes raw hither, without any inſtruction at all.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: So ſhould every Witneſs: God forbid we ſhould countenance the inſtructing of Witneſſes what they ſhould ſwear.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: I beg your pardon, my Lord, I did hope this favour might be granted: I will then ask him ſome queſtions.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Justice.
sp.p: Ay, ay, do, refreſh his memory by queſtions as much as you can. Come, I'll ask him ſome queſtions for you; Do you remember you ſaw Mr. Oates at any time in the year 78?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: If it pleaſe your Lordſhip, as near as I can remember I ſaw him in May before the Plot was diſcovered.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: That was the year 78.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: I am ſure I did ſee him about that time.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: Where did you ſee him?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: I was a Servant to Sir Richard Barker, and Mr. Oates I had been acquainted with before he went to Sea; he us'd to come to my Maſters houſe frequently, and divers times he din'd at the Table, and I waited upon my Maſter there.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: When was that he din'd there at the Table?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: A year before that time, in May that I ſpoke of before: It was before he went to Sea.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: When did you ſee him again?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: After he came from Sea, I ſaw him at my Maſters houſe.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Justice.
sp.p: When was it that he went to Sea?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: It was a year or two before the May that I ſaw him diſguis'd coming to my Maſters houſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Ay, what diſguiſe did he come in?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: His hair was cut off, cloſe cropt to his ears, and an old white Hat over his head, and a ſhort gray Coat over like a Horſe mans Coat.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: How came you to take ſuch notice of him at that time, as to be able to ſwear when this was?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: I was call'd preſently after for a Witneſs.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: How long after this was it, that you were call'd to be a Witneſs?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: It was when the Trials were at the Old Bailey.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: Was this the firſt time you had recollected theſe circumſtances?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, that was the firſt time.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: Then how came you a year and a halfs time afterwards to remember the preciſe month of May, when you did not know you ſhould be call'd to queſtion about it, and yet you cannot remember the time particularly when Oates went to Sea, but take the compaſs of a year or two?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: I gueſs it was a year before, I cannot exactly tell.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: When you can but gueſs at the time of ſuch a remarkable paſſage within the compaſs of a year or two, how can you pitch upon the very month for ſuch a thing as this is a year and halfs time after?

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: No, my Lord, it was not ſo long as a year and a half.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: Pray Sir have patience.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, the Records ſhew that Ireland's Trial was the 17th. of December 78, and the Five Jeſuits Trial was the 15th. of June 79.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: Then it is a full twelve months time and more from the May that he ſays he ſaw you at Sir Richard Barker's, to Whitebread's Tryal, in which he was examin'd the firſt time. Now that which I deſire of him is, to give me a reaſon why he remembers it was in the May was twelve-month before.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: My Lord, The Lady whom I did ſerve, dy'd in February before, that year:

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: But give me ſome reaſon of your remembrance ſo long after.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: My Lord, I do as well as I can.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: Well, what is it?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: My Lady was buried in February, and he comes into the Yard where I was cleaning my Coach, in May following that February, which was May before the Diſcovery of the Plot. He ask'd me what alteration was in the Family? I told him my Lady was dead, and the Eſcutcheon was over the door for her. He ask'd for Doctor Tongue when he came firſt in the houſe.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: Why ſhould he ask for Doctor Tongue?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: My Lord, Doctor Tongue lodg'd there and he did ask for him: I come to juſtifie the Truth; upon my Salvation what I ſay is true.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: Well, when he ask'd whether Doctor Tongue was within, what ſaid you?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: I told him no, but he went into the Room where Doctor Tongue us'd to lie, but found him not there: So he went out again; that was the ſame time Mrs. Mayo ſaw him.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: But, Friend, prethee mind what I ask thee, becauſe thou muſt give me ſatisfaction how thou com'ſt to remember this, ſo as to be able to ſwear it; for his going to ask for Tongue, or the Eſcutcheon being over the door, neither of thoſe can be a reaſon for you to remember that this was in May, for the Eſcutcheon may be up in June, or in July, or in Auguſt, or in any other month after the time you ſpeak of: But how came you to take notice of this buſineſs that it was in May?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Sir Richard Barker my Maſter was then ſick at Putney, which was in May, though I cannot ſpeak to a day or a week particularly.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: Then prethee let me ask thee this queſtion, How long had your Maſter been ſick before that?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: He had never been well ſince my Lady dy'd.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: When was it that your Lady dy'd?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: In February before.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How long after that did your Maſter Sir Richard Barker continue ſick?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Half a year, I believe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Why then, ſuppoſe your Maſter fell ſick immediately after your Lady died, and he continued ſick half a year after, yet all this while Oates might come during his ſickneſs even in the month of June or July, when 'tis acknowledg'd he was in Town, and not be here in February, which is teſtified by a great many Witneſſes.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: My Lord, I tell your Lordſhip the Truth, it was in May.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But how doſt thou come to take notice it was in the month of May, ſo as to be able to ſwear it?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: My Lord, I tell your Lordſhip my Lady was dead, and the Eſcutcheon was over the door.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: So it might be, tho' he came in June or July, I tell ye.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: My Maſter was ſick at Putney at that time.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How long did he lie ſick at Putney?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: He was ſick there a fortnight, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Then prethee when did thy Maſter go to Putney?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: I cannot tell to a day.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: In what month was it that he went?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: It was the latter-end of April, my Lord, as I remember.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How long continu'd he ſick at Putney?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: The matter of a fortnight.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was not your Maſter ſick when your Lady dy'd at Putney?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: No, he was not there then.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When did he go to Putney, ſay ye?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: He went not thither till the latter-end of April, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And did he continue at Putney but a fortnight.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Not at a time, but he continu'd going and coming a quarter of a year.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But this was the firſt time of his going, was it:

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Yes, as I do remember.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, he is my Witneſs, and I deſire I may examine him.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Hold there, Mr. Oates; he is mine too: all the Witneſſes are mine to ſatisfie me in the truth of the Fact.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: And to ſatisfie the Jury too, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Yes, and to ſatisfie the Jury too; but I muſt and will ſift out the truth, for both our ſatisfactions.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, it is now, come the next month, ſix years ago ſince the Evidence of this matter was firſt given by theſe Witneſſes.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Then, Mr. Oates, I'll come a little rounder to you, and I'll put you into a certain way of clearing this buſineſs. I'll tell you what you ſhall do; You had a Lodging in Town, as well as Diet, and as well as you did eat at Doctor Barker's ſometimes, ſo you eat and lay ſometimes elſewhere. You were here in Town a great while together, if your own aſſertions be true; for you were from April till June in Town. Now come and give us account by ſome Witneſſes, if you can, where did you lodge at that time, and where did you diet? for it ſeems you had but one meal at Sir Richard Barker's.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Is that the queſtion, Sir, here in hand.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Ay indeed is it, and the main one too.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: I beg your Lordſhips pardon if I miſtake, but I think that is not now in queſtion; for theſe St. Omers men do ſwear, That I was all April and May at St. Omers: Then if I do prove that in April and May I was not at St. Omers, but here in London, it is argument good enough againſt them that their Evidence is falſe. And indeed, can your Lordſhip or the Jury expect that I being then engag'd among & for the Papiſts, & afterwards an Evidence againſt them to diſcover their Treaſons, can bring any of them to teſtifie for me now? No, they will as certainly forſwear themſelves, as theſe young Fellows have all done.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Let me ask you a ſhorter queſtion; Did you always lie in a Papiſt houſe, all the two months you ſay you were here.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I lay at ſeveral houſes.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Tell me the names of thoſe houſes, or any of them.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: It is not to the point in queſtion here, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſtice.
sp.p: Yes it is very much; But I perceive it is a Secret, and let any body judge why.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, They that have by the principles of their Religion, Liberty, to affirm or deny any thing, and can have diſpenſations for the violations of Oaths and Sacraments, certainly are not to be admitted as witneſſes in ſuch a caſe as this.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſtice.
sp.p: Talk not to me of Diſpenſations and I know not what; I ſpeak from a plain demonſtrative Proof: can it be believed that you ſhould be here in England ſo long, and as they ſay, publickly, and no perſon living ſee you that we can hear of, but an Old Woman that never ſaw you, nor knew you before, and a Coachman that tells a wild ſtory without reaſon: if you will not tell me where you lay, can you tell me where you did eat all that time.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: I can tell where I did lye that time.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do ſo then. Let us hear it, that will be your beſt defence.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Is that the point My Lord, in queſtion.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Ay upon my word is it the main point in this Caſe.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: If it ſhould go upon that foot my Lord, it is impoſſible for me now to prove it; for 'tis well known I lay ſometimes with Mr. Whitebread, and ſometimes with Mr. Mico, neither of which can I have to teſtify for me; and beſides, I muſt inſiſt upon it, theſe things were in queſtion at Whitebreads Trial, nor do I believe that Mr. Whitebread, if askt at his death, would have juſtified, and ſtood by it, that I was not here then.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, This I muſt certainly ſay, I cannot help it, but it will ſtick with me till better anſwered. I can never be ſatisfied, that if you were here ſo long, there ſhould no better evidence be produc'd to prove you here.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, nor can I help your diſſatisfaction, but I am to ſatisfy all that hear me this day, that it is a very hard Caſe that is put upon me; I have taken the moſt effectual courſe that I could, to provide for Evidence to make my defence, and I think, by your Lordſhips good leave, thoſe that I have produc'd, do prove me here in Town in April and May 78. And if your Lordſhip has done with this Witneſs, I'le call another.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, go on as you will. I tell you what ſticks with me.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray call Mr. Philip Page.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Hold Sir a little, I would ask theſe Witneſſes a few Queſtions before they go away. You Butler, let me ask you, pray, the firſt time you ſaw Mr. Oates at the time you ſpeak of, was it in April or May?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He ſwore it was the beginning of May.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: To the beſt of my knowledge, it was the beginning of May.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Who did you tell firſt, that there was Mr. Oates at that time?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: I told it Mrs. Mayo.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Conſider Friend, what you ſay now, you are upon your Oath, and conſider what you ſaid at the former Trial, when you were upon your Oath too.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray, My Lord, I deſire my Witneſſes may be Examined without Threatnings.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſtice.
sp.p: It is not a Threatning, it is an Admonition not to go beyond the Truth.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Be ſure you be in the Right in what you ſay, and now I ask you upon your Oath, when was the firſt time you ſaw Mr. Oates when he came in that diſguiſe you ſpeak of?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: I told you it was in May Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: How far in May, conſider well what you ſay.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: To the beſt of my remembrance, it was the beginning of May.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Do you think it was within a Week, or the Firſt Ten days of May?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: I cannot tell that, as well as I remember, it was the beginning of May.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: When you ſaw him firſt in May, who elſe, as you remember, was by?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Mrs. Mayo.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: And no body elſe?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Yes, One Benjamin Turbet, who is ſince dead.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: But conſider your Oath Friend, once more, and recollect your ſelf, do you ſwear poſitively Mrs. Mayo was by, and did ſee him at the ſame time?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: I ſee her look out of the Window into the Yard, and I believe ſhe did ſee him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Well then, let us examine her Evidence and yours together, and ſee how they agree.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, theſe are not queſtions tending to ſatisfy the Jury at all, as to the point in queſtion.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Are they not, methinks they are, whatſoever you think.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: After Six years time, to ask ſuch poor ignorant people ſuch trifling queſtions!

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Pray Sir be contented, and let the Kings Council examine the Witneſſes.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, he ſays I was here in May, that's enough.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well Sir, I know what he ſays.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: And you ſhall hear Mr. Oates, how your Witneſſes agree.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Go on Mr. Sollicitor, and do you ſit ſtill and be quiet.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Then my Lord, I would ask him this queſtion more, the firſt time you ſaw Oates come to Sir Richard Barkers, what habit pray you was he in?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: He was in a diſguiſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Ay, what diſguiſe?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: He had a White Hat flapping over his Ears, his Hair cut ſhort, cloſe to his Ears, and a grey ſhort Coat.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Had he never a Periwig on?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: No, his Hair was cut ſhort to his Ears.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hauſes.
sp.p: Was he in ſuch a diſguiſe, that a Man might not ordinarily know him, that had known him before?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Truly my Lord, I did not know him when he firſt came in, till he ſpoke to me, and asked me, how do you John; and then I recollected who he was, that it was Mr. Oates.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Was he always in the ſame Habit, when he came thither?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: The next time he came, he had a Cinnamon coloured Suit, and a long black Periwig that was curl'd down thus far, and a black Hat with a green Ribbon and green Cuff-ſtrings about his Wriſts.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did you ever ſee Oates dine there?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Yes I did.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When was that?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: After my Maſter came home from Putney.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who was there beſides?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: One Sir William Thurrell and Madam Thurrell.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How often did he dine there?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Several times.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who elſe was there?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: My Maſter and his Daughter.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And who elſe.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Mrs. Mayo.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What is become of your Maſters Daughter?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: I beg your pardon for that my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where is ſhe Man?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: She is at home I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What doſt thou beg my pardon for then?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: My Lord, I call to mind ſhe did not dine with them.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did ſhe dine at any time with him there?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Yes, I remember ſeveral times, but not then.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When did you ſee your Maſters Daughter laſt?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: I have not ſeen her this Quarter of this Year.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where is ſhe now?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: At home at Putney my Lord, I believe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And ſhe was ſeveral times there when he din'd there.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Yes, She was at home.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did Mrs. Mayo ſee him at Dinner there?

sp.speaker: Butler,
sp.p: Yes, I believe ſhe did.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How often did he dine there about this time you ſpeak of?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Several times.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do you think ſeven times?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: I do think he might have din'd there ſeven times.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did he more than ſeven times do you think?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: I cannot number how many times it was.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Now come in Mrs. Mayo again.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: Here I am my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Mrs. Mayo, give me leave to ask you a queſtion or two.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: Yes my Lord what you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You ſay (if I do not miſ-remember; if I do, I beg your pardon, and you'l correct me) a week in May was the firſt time you ſaw Mr. Oates, and that was at Sir Richard Barkers.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: I think it might be about the beginning of May.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Had he been in the Houſe before?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: Not at that time that I know of, but as they told me.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who told you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: That Coach-man there John Butler, and one Benjamin who liv'd in the Houſe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Then you did not ſee him the firſt time he came; what ſay you Butler?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: She did ſee him out of the Window in the yard.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well let that paſs then, come I'le ask you another queſtion upon your Oath, how often have you ſeen him dine there?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: I ſaw him dine that time that I ſpoke of.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did not he dine there above once?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: No he did not.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What ſay you Butler?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: He did dine there ſeveral times with them.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Then one of you two muſt be miſtaken I am ſure.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, if your Lordſhip would pleaſe to give me leave to ſpeak, I would ſet it right.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Good Sir let them ſet themſelves right if they can, we need none of your Inſtructions.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire—

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Why, how now; pray Sir be at quiet. Mrs. Mayo, pray what Habit had Oates when you ſaw him firſt?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: He was in a grey Hat and a grey Coat.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was his hair ſhort or long?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: He had on a kind of a ſhort Wigg.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: You are ſure it was a Wigg.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: Yes, a kind of a brown Perriwigg.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And he ſays his hair was cut ſhort to his ears.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Theſe things are very lean ſtuff to perjure a Witneſs upon.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: When he came the ſecond time what Cloaths had he on?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: Afterwards he came in black Cloaths and a long Perriwig.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hauſes.
sp.p: What coloured Perriwig was that, a black or a white one?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: Not a black but a brown.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: You ſay it was long.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: Longer than his other, yet not very long neither.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Here are I know not how many Contradictions in theſe Witneſſes Teſtimonies.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Truly my Lord, I do not find in the Examination of the St. Omers Witneſſes, you were ſo ſtrict, or bore half ſo hard upon them, as you do upon my Witneſſes, what does it ſignifie my Lord, whether the Wigg were long or ſhort, black or brown?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: We have no other way to detect Perjuries, but by theſe Circumſtances; and 'tis the duty of a Judge to enquire into all Particulars: as in a Controverſie about words, were they ſpoken in Latin or in Engliſh, and ſo to all places and poſtures of ſitting, riding, or the like; as you know the Perjury of the Elders in the caſe of Suſanna, was by their different Teſtimony in particular Circumſtances diſcovered.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I will ask her but one ſhort queſtion, by the Oath you have taken Mrs. Mayo, to ſpeak the Truth, the whole Truth, and nothing but the Truth, as you expect the face of God with comfort in another World; did you ſee me at Sir Richard Barkers at any time in May 78. the May before the Plot was diſcovered? for that is the main queſtion.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: Yes I did, and I ſpeak nothing here, but what I ſpeak as in the preſence of the Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Prithee Woman doſt thou think we ask thee any thing that we think thou doſt not ſpeak in the preſence of the Lord; we are all of us in the preſence of the Lord always.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: And ſhall anſwer before him for all that we have done and ſaid, all of us, the proudeſt and the greateſt here.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But I would not have ſo much to anſwer for as thou haſt in this buſineſs for all the World.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Well we have done with her now, ſhe may go away.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where does ſhe live now?

sp.speaker: Cryer.
sp.p: Mrs. Mayo where do you live now?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: In Leaden-hall-ſtreet my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When did you ſee Sir Richard Barker's Daughter?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: About a Fortnight ago.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: In Barbican in London.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do you live with Sir Richard Barker now?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo,
sp.p: I do not live with him now.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did his Daughter uſe to be at the Table at dinner?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: She was often in the Country my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did ſhe eat at his Table at that time when Oates was there?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: I am not able to ſay whether ſhe did or not; ſhe uſed to be in Wales at Sir Thomas Middleton's ſometimes, and with Madam Thurrell her Aunt, who was her Mothers Siſter and her two Daughters.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: In Wales doſt thou ſay, where?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: My Lord in your own Country at one Doctor Cockets: I know your Lordſhip, though your Lordſhip does not know me.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I am very glad of it good Woman; but prithee did ever Sir Richard Barker dine with Mr. Oates?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mayo.
sp.p: I cannot ſay he did, he went to and fro.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, have you any more Witneſſes?

sp.speaker: Oates,
sp.p: Cryer, call Philip Page.

sp.speaker: Cryer.
sp.p: Here he is Sir.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray ſwear him, (which was done) pray be pleaſed to give my Lord and the Jury the beſt account you can of my being in Town. But Mr. Page, the queſtion that I firſt ask you, is whether I was here in April or May, and in what year it was that you did ſee me at your Maſters Houſe?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When did you ſee Mr. Oates at your Maſter's Houſe? you mean Sir Richard Barker to be his Maſter I ſuppoſe?

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Yes my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What do you ſay to it?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Truly I cannot be poſitive to the year, but to the beſt of my remembrance it was 78.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray tell my Lord and the Jury ſome Circumſtances in that year that did happen to you, that makes you believe it was 78.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Sir, I'le give you the beſt ſatisfaction I can to the beſt of my knowledge; he came to Sir Richard Barker's one evening, and there he enquired for Doctor Tongue: he was in a diſguiſe, in a light coloured Coat, ſomething like to Frize, but it was not Frize; the term that they give it, I cannot ſo readily tell: he had his hair cut ſhort almoſt to his ears, and he had a broad-brim'd Hat on, and a ſmall ſtick in his hand, walking melancholly about the Hall: I happening to be the firſt body he met with as I ſuppoſe, he asked me if Doctor Tongue was within; I told him no, I had not ſeen him of a conſiderable time: he then asked me where Sir Richard Barker was; I told him he was ill now at Putney; ſays he, when will he be here; I told him I could not tell.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did he ſee any body there but you?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: That I cannot tell my Lord, not that I know of.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What time of the year was it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: And what Month?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: What year and what month it was I am not able to ſay my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What became of him after that?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
He went out of our Gates then: Sir, he was walking up and down melancholy, and not finding any one, as I ſuppoſe, to anſwer him, he continued walking in
the Patients Hall, where they uſed to wait on Sir Richard Barker, that came to diſcourſe with him about Phyſick; and upon my anſwer to his queſtion he went away.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did you ever ſee him any other time near to that time?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: No, I did not.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did you uſe to wait on Table?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: No, I did not.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What Service were you then engaged in at Sir Richard Barker's?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: I made up the Phyſick my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did you not acquaint the Coach-man, nor Mrs. Mayo, nor Sir Richard Barker with it?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: I think Sir Richard Barker was in Town ſoon after, and I did acquaint him with it.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: But can't you tell what time this is Sir?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: I can ſay no other than I have ſaid; I believe it was in 78.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was this in June, July, or May, or when?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: I cannot ſay punctually what month it was my Lord; but to the beſt of my knowledge and remembrance, it was in the beginning of May.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Had not your Maſter a Patient at Iſlington at that time, that was ſick of a Feaver?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Yes he had.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Withens.
sp.p: Why would Mr. Oates have given the Patient Phyſick?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: No my Lord, but 'twas about that time that the Patient was under my Maſter's Cure.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Indeed the St. Omers men do ſwear thorough ſtitch, but my honeſt Witneſſes are cautious, it being ſo long ago; and he that is a Miniſter of the Church of England, (as they ſay) ſpeaks to a very day, upon a much ſlighter Circumſtance: pray call Mr. William Walker.

sp.speaker: Cryer.
sp.p: Here he is.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Swear him; (which was done) be pleaſed, Walker, to give my Lord to underſtand, when 'twas you ſaw me here in London in diſguiſe; and when it was you ſwore ſix years agone at the Old-Bayly, that you ſaw me here in London: Sir, the time in Controverſie is this; I came here to diſcover a Plot of the Papiſts againſt the Kings Life and the Religion, and I ſwore—

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You muſt not ask queſtions in that manner. It is propereſt for you to propoſe your queſtions to the Court, and they will ask the Witneſſes.

sp.speaker: Oates.
