sp.p: Then I will not ask him, but propoſe it to your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Ay, propoſe what queſtions you pleaſe, and if they are fair I'le ask them.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Then my Lord I would ask Mr. Walker this queſtion; when 'twas he met me with a diſguiſe, in what year and what month.

sp.speaker: Mr. Walker.
sp.p: My Lord, I have been interrogated in former times upon this point, ſix or ſeven years ago, and I do confeſs I did ſee the man, and met him between St. Martins-lane and Leiceſter-fields; and truly my Lord I think I may ſay it was my unhappineſs to meet with him; for I have had a great deal of trouble by it ſince, Subpoena upon Subpoena, trouble after trouble, that I am even weary of it; for I am an old man: but I do ſay I did meet him at that end of the Town, between St. Martins-lane and Leiceſter-fields in a ſtrange diſguiſe, he was juſt like a Vagrant, a very Raſcal, and that's true I believe, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did you know him before?

sp.speaker: Mr. Walker.
sp.p: Yes, or I had not known him then.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When was this?

sp.speaker: Mr. Walker.
sp.p: My Lord I'le tell you, my Lord Chief Juſtice Scroggs, when I was at the Old-Bayly, asked me if I knew what time it was, I ſaw him thus; ſaid I my Lord, 'tis almoſt a year and a half ſince I ſaw him: and I being an old man, little thought it worth the while to lay up the particular time in my Memory; but I'le caſt about in my thoughts to make the beſt conjecture I can; for now I will not be upon my Oath, it being but conjecture.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But now you are upon your Oath, remember that, man.

sp.speaker: Mr. Walker.
sp.p: My Lord, I am ſpeaking what I ſaid to the Court at that time.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Pray do not tell us an old tedious Story of the queſtions and anſwers in the Old-Bayly; but mind what is ſaid to you here: my queſtion is now, what time you ſaw Oates diſguiſed between St. Martins-lane and Leiceſter-fields as you ſay you did.

sp.speaker: Mr. Walker.
sp.p: My Lord, I cannot preſcribe the time, but I'le gueſs as near as I can with the beſt probability, and that is, upon this circumſtance; when I went forward into Leiceſter-fields, in the Court before the Houſe, I ſaw the Elm-Trees budded forth as big as an Hazle-Nut: ſo that I did conjecture by that Token, it might be between Lady-day, the latter end of April; that was the time as near as I could gueſs.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: In what year was that?

sp.speaker: Mr. Walker.
sp.p: I cannot very well tell what year it was.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was it in 77 or 78.

sp.speaker: Mr. Walker.
sp.p: Truly my Lord, I never thought it worth ſo much taking notice of, to fix the particular time in my memory.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Whether was it that year the Plot was diſcovered, or the Michaelmaſs following.

sp.speaker: Mr. Walker.
sp.p: I cannot tell when the Plot was diſcovered, or whether it be found out yet or no?

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: But was it the year before you were Examined?

sp.speaker: Mr. Walker.
sp.p: To aſwer you Mr. Oates, when it was exactly, I cannot ſay; truly I would give you the beſt ſatisfaction I could, and do you as much right as I would do my ſelf; I think if that time when I was Examined, were in 77 or 78, it was near a year and a quarter before I did ſee you.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, what can you make of this?

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: 'Tis not to be ſuppoſed he is a very willing Witneſs, but yet he ſays, 'twas a year and a quarter, before the Trial in which he was Examined, which muſt be in April 78.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I would know this queſtion of you: were you preſent at the Old-Bayley, when the Five Jeſuits were Tried?

sp.speaker: Mr. Walker.
sp.p: I was there my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Were you at any Trial but one?

sp.speaker: Mr. Walker.
sp.p: I was not Examin'd at any time but one.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Have you any more queſtions to ask him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Walker.
sp.p: My Lord Chief Juſtice that then was, did ask me if I knew any of the Priſoners at the Bar, and I look'd upon all of them, and I ſaid I knew not either of them.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray my Lord, ask him whether he was not produc'd, when the St. Omers Men were produc'd, and gave his evidence as to my being in Town at that time.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He hears the Queſtion, let him anſwer it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Walker.
sp.p: I am not able to anſwer you, becauſe you put ſeveral Queſtions together; but this I ſay, I was never Examined but once, though I have been Subpoena'd often, to my great torment and trouble.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Did you give Evidence at that Trial, that you ſaw me in April 78?

sp.speaker: Mr. Walker.
sp.p: I teſtified that I ſaw you, and by ſuch circumſtances, it muſt be about ſuch a time as well as I could ſuggeſt; but I could not, nor cannot ſpeak poſitively.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Now my Lord, I ſhall go on to another part of my Evidence, and call ſome other Witneſſes, and firſt of all, I come to Mr. Serjeant Maynard, and I deſire he may be ſworn.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What do you ask my Brother Maynard?

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: I call Mr. Serjeant Maynard to give an account of the Proceedings of the Houſe of Commons upon my Diſcovery of the Popiſh Plot.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: We will not admit that to be any Evidence at all; nor can it be by Law.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, Mr. Serjeant Maynard was one of the Committee of the Houſe of Commons that managed the Impeachment, and can give an account of the Evidence and Records that were produc'd at the Trial of the late Viſcount Stafford.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Maynard.
sp.p: I know nothing truly, nor can remember any thing of it now.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He ſays, he remembers nothing.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Maynard.
sp.p: If Mr. Oates had told me before hand, when he Subpoena'd me, what time, and what particular things he would have Examin'd me to, probably if I was there, I have Notes that I then took, but I can never ſwear to my Memory, for any Cauſe ſo long ago.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I am very ſorry Mr. Serjeant Maynard's Age ſhould ſo impair his Memory.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I dare ſay, you are not more ſorry than he is for his Age.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Well my Lord, I cannot help it: Then I deſire Mr. Blayney may be ak'd whether he has his Notes of my Lord Stafford's Trial.

sp.speaker: Mr. Blayney.
sp.p: No, my Lord, I have them not here; Mr. Oates by his Ticket of his Subpoena, deſir'd only the Notes of Ireland, Whitebread and Langhorns Trial.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But I muſt tell you Mr. Oates, if thoſe Notes were here, they could be of no uſe to you without the Record of my Lord Stafford's Attainder; if you ask any thing upon another Trial, you muſt produce firſt the Record of that Trial, and then you may examine to what was given in Evidence at the Trial.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, it is of Record in the Houſe of Lords.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But that we are not to take notice of, without the Record be brought in Evidence before us: we muſt go according to the courſe of Law in all Caſes.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Then my Lord, I muſt betake my ſelf to another part of my defence, and that is to prove the frequent attempts made to baffle the Diſcovery of this Popiſh Plot, and to ſtifle the Murder of Sir Edmundbury Godfrey, and to fling it upon a Proteſtant Peer.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But that is no Evidence neither.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Holloway.
sp.p: Surely that is very Collateral Evidence.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Nay, it is no Evidence at all in this Caſe; we muſt not admit of any ſuch Evidence to be given.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Good my Lord, if this had not been true, which was ſworn by Witneſſes that had diſcovered the Plot, why ſhould theſe Men appear to ſuborn Witneſſes (and they have been Convicted of Subornation, and endeavouring) to baffle the Diſcovery, particularly as to Juſtice Godfrey's Death?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Mr. Oates, I muſt keep you to Evidence that is proper; we are upon our Oaths to go according to Law, and the Jury are upon their Oaths to Try this Cauſe according to their Evidence; and we are bound to give them this advice in point of Law, that nothing muſt weigh, or have any conſideration with them, that you offer if it be not legal and proper Evidence: if you can ſay and prove that any of the Witneſſes that have been produc'd this day againſt you, have been tamper'd with; or that they have tamper'd with any of the former Evidence, that is a good Evidence againſt them; but it muſt not be by any means admitted that the time of the Court be taken up, or the Jury enveigled by that which has not a natural tendency to the buſineſs before us.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: But if your Lordſhip pleaſe, this Conſult in April 78. was diſcovered to the Houſe of Commons among the other parts of the Diſcovery of the Treaſons of ſeveral Noble Men and Gentlemen: now upon the whole diſcovery of the Plot, I would deſire that I might give in proof the Proceedings of the Houſe of Commons.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: No, no, you cannot.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray my Lord, is not the Journal of the Houſe of Commons Evidence?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: No, we ſay it is not at all.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Is that the Opinion of the whole Court my Lord?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Yes, undoubtedly, there is no queſtion of it.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Is any Record of the Houſe of Lords Evidence?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Yes, I tell you it is, and that becauſe it is a Record; but there is a vaſt difference between the Records of the Houſe of Lords, and the Journals of the Houſe of Commons.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: The Journals have been delivered in as Evidence before now.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I cannot tell what they have been, but I am ſure they ought not to be, and whatever they have been elſewhere, they cannot be here; and I'le tell you a plain reaſon for it, becauſe they have not ſo much power in the Houſe of Commons as to give an Oath: but the Houſe of Peers is a Court of Record, and therefore their Proceedings are Evidence as the Proceedings of the Kings Bench here; or any other Court of Record are.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Then my Lord if that part of my Evidence be over-rul'd; before I come to ſumm up my Evidence, I deſire to offer this thing. My Lord, I can produce ſeveral Members of the Houſe of Commons in the ſeveral Parliaments, that can remember how they proceeded againſt the Lords in the Tower, and the Popiſh Traitors upon my Diſcovery, and what credit I had in the Houſe of Commons; Will that be Evidence pray my Lord?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: No, it will not, if you will produce any one that you told this to before the publick Diſcovery, that may be Evidence ſuch as it is, and is often allow'd; but what the Houſe of Commons did upon the Diſcovery, that's not any Evidence at all.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Then my Lord, ſuppoſe I can prove, that I gave an Early and Timely account to any of the Houſe of Lords of this Conſpiracy, and did acquaint them with the Conſult in April as part of it; I deſire to know whether in producing any of thoſe Lords, I ſhall give that which is Evidence.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Call whom you will that you told any thing to, that is a ſort of Evidence, I tell you?

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Then I call my Lord of Devonſhire.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Here is my Lord of Devonſhire.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I beg your pardon for the trouble I put your Lordſhip to; but your Lordſhip ſees the neceſſity of it it is for the juſtification of the Truth, to which I will give my Blood for a Seal if I be call'd to it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: My Lord of Devonſhire, your Lordſhip muſt be ſworn (which was done.)

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Will your Lordſhip be pleaſed to acquaint the Court and the Jury (your Lordſhip being at that time a Member of the Commons Houſe) what an account I gave there of this particular Conſult (to keep to that point that is here in queſtion) before the Court this day, and with what credit I was received in all theſe Parliaments; for my Credit and the Credit of the Parliament is now in queſtion.

sp.speaker: E. of Devonſhire.
sp.p: My Lord, all I can ſay to it is this; you Mr. Oates gave a long account of a Conſult and Conſpiracy among the Jeſuits: but I cannot remember any particular, it is ſo long ago.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Every Body knows this, you gave a long Narrative into the Houſe of Commons and Houſe of Lords too.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Ay, and it was a true one; but my Lord of Devonſhire, I deſire your Lordſhip would be pleaſed to give the Court and the Jury an account, with what credit I was received in thoſe Three Parliaments your Lordſhip ſat as Member in.

sp.speaker: E. of Devonſhire.
sp.p: I remember that the two Weſtminſter Parliaments after the long Parliament, were ſo ſatisfied with the Diſcovery, that they paſſed a Vote in the Houſe of Commons—

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: The Votes of the Houſe of Commons are no Evidence at all.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: They ſhow what opinion the Parliament was of.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Many Votes that have been made of late, I hope will neither be Evidence for, nor put in practice again.

sp.speaker: E. of Devonſhire.
sp.p: My Lord, it is well known to all the World the Vote I ſpeak of.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Nay my Lord I ſpeak not to your Lordſhip; for we all know thoſe Votes that I ſpeak of were not according to your Lordſhips mind: But we only ſay thus in General, that becauſe the Houſe of Commons cannot give an Oath, therefore what is done there, is not an Evidence here, or in any Court of Record.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: But my Lord, that I muſt urge, I do perceive that in the time of Parliament, and during the Sitting of the Houſe of Commons, Votes have been brought in as Barrs to the Proceedings of Inferior Courts; and this Court does not look upon it ſelf as Superior to the Great Court of Parliament, and then if they may be brought—

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Which they cannot be, nor never were, nor I am ſure ought to be; nor I hope never will be as long as there is any Juſtice in the Nation.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: But my Lord you will allow the Records of the Houſe of Lords to be Evidence?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Yes, I tell you I will, and for that reaſon, becauſe they are Records out of a Court of Record: an Order of Court Baron is no Evidence, becauſe it is no Court of Record; but a Judgment of a Court Leet is Evidence, becauſe it is a Court of Record; and there's the difference.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I call in the next place my Lord of Angleſey, if he be in Court.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: No, he is not here.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray will you give me leave to call my Lord Keeper then?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: See in the Court of Chancery, whether my Lord Keeper be there.

sp.speaker: Cryer.
sp.p: No my Lord he is not; he is gone.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: He was Subpoena'd my Lord, and I can have Affidavit made of it: he was a material Witneſs for me.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I cannot help it; he is not here.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray call my Lord Chief Baron.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Go one of you into the Exchequer, and ſee if my Lord Chief Baron be there, and tell him Mr. Oates calls for him as a Witneſs.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: And Mr. Juſtice Levins.

sp.speaker: Cryer.
sp.p: The Courts are both up; and they are all gone.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: They were ſubpoena'd I am ſure to be here; well go and ſee whether they are there or no.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: In the mean time do you call ſome other Witneſſes.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: I call my Lord Chief Juſtice Jones.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: The Cryer is gone to look for the Judges.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Then I call my Lord of Clare.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Here is my Lord of Clare.

sp.speaker: E. of Clare.
sp.p: My Lord I can remember nothing it is ſo long time ago.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: My Lord of Clare ſays he can remember nothing.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: I only call my Lord of Clare to ask him one queſtion which I hope his Lordſhip will remember.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Swear my Lord of Clare, (which was done;) well what is it you ask my Lord?

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord of Clare, the queſtion I would ask your Lordſhip is, with what credit I was received in the Houſe of Lords upon my Diſcovery; and that you will to the beſt of your memory, give my Lord and the Jury an account, how the Houſe of Peers proceeded upon my Evidence.

sp.speaker: E. of Clare.
sp.p: Truly my Lord I cannot give any account; it is of ſo long ſtanding.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: It is a great while ago my Lord, and therefore it is hard meaſure that I muſt be brought to this Tryal ſo long after.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: If it be a long time, we cannot help it: we cannot force People to proſecute ſooner than they will do.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: I deſire Mr. Baron Gregory may be called.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He is not here, but ſee and call my Brother Gregory; I hear they are all together in the Treaſury.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Then I call Mr. Williams that was Speaker in the Houſe of Commons.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Here is Mr. Williams, (he was ſworn.)

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: I deſire, Mr. Williams, becauſe you were then Speaker of the Commons Houſe of Parliament, you would be pleaſed to tell what you remember concerning the credit I received in that Parliament in which you were Speaker, upon the Diſcovery I made of the Popiſh Plot; and particularly as to the Conſult of Jeſuits to kill the late King in the month of April. 78.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: My Lord, my Memory is never very good; but eſpecially in a caſe that is at ſuch a diſtance of time, and which conſiſts of ſo many Particulars as this, I mean Mr. Oates Diſcovery. But this my Lord I do remember; he was examin'd at the Bar of the Houſe of Commons and gave a long account: but it is more than any man can do to tell every Particular that is ſaid in that Houſe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was he upon his Oath, Mr. Williams, at the Bar of the Houſe of Commons?

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: My Lord, he was as other men are that are examin'd in the Houſe of Commons.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: We all know it could not be upon Oath, they have not Power to give an Oath.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: What Reputation he was of, I cannot ſay ſo well as what their Proceedings did teſtifie.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Nor in caſe they did believe him never ſo much, is it any thing to this queſtion, which is, whether he ſwore true or falſe at Ireland's Tryal.

sp.speaker: Mr. Wiliams.
sp.p: My Lord, when a Perſon is brought to the Barr, there to be a Witneſs in any Cauſe, every body is ſilent, and the Witneſs is heard what he has to ſay; and ſo was Mr. Oates: when he had done he withdrew; but what the Opinion of the Houſe was upon it, I muſt ſubmit to their Votes and Reſolutions.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Which you know Mr. Williams, are no Evidence.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: That I muſt ſubmit to the Court.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: I deſire my Lord of Clare would be pleaſed to tell, if he remembers, what Credit the Houſe of Lords gave me upon my Diſcovery.

sp.speaker: E. of Clare.
sp.p: My Lord, I do not well hear Mr. Oates queſtion.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, my queſtion is this, when I was brought to the Bar of the Lords Houſe, whether I did not receive the thanks of the Lords Houſe for my Diſcovery?

sp.speaker: E. of Clare.
sp.p: Truly Sir, at the beginning of the Diſcovery of the Popiſh Plot, I was not in Town, nor in the Houſe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But now Mr. Oates I hope you are ſatisfied by the anſwer that is given by your own Witneſs, that what is done in the Houſe of Commons, is no Evidence; and I would have you remember that is the Reaſon of it, becauſe they are no Court of Record, and becauſe they cannot ſo much as give an Oath.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I ſee my Lord of Huntingdon is here; and tho I did not Subpoena his Lordſhip, nor deſign'd to have troubled him; yet being here, I deſire his Lordſhip would give the Court an account what Credit I had in the Houſe of Lords upon my Diſcovery.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Swear my Lord of Huntingdon (which was done.)

sp.speaker: E. of Huntingdon.
sp.p:
I do believe my Lord, Mr. Oates Diſcovery found a good reception in the Houſe of Lords; but it was grounded upon the opinion, that what he ſaid was true, and that he was an honeſt man: for ſo the Houſe then accounted him to be; and upon this it was their Lordſhips gave credit to his Teſtimony; and indeed had the matter been true, it was of high Importance to have it thorougly examined: But ſince that time it being apparent there were ſo many, and great Contradictions, Falſities, and Perjuries
in his Evidence; upon which ſo much innocent blood hath been ſhed, I believe a great many Perſons who were concerned in the Trials of thoſe unfortunate men, are heartily afflicted and ſorry for their ſhare in it: And I do believe moſt of the Houſe of Peers have altered their opinion, as to this mans credit; and look upon his Evidence as I do, to be very falſe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do you hear him Mr. Oates?

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: No my Lord, I do not very well.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Then my Lord of Huntingdon turn your face to the Jury; and ſay what you ſaid to us over again.

p.hi: Which his Lordſhip did to the ſame Effect.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Very well my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Withens.
sp.p: There's your Credit with the Houſe of Lords, Mr. Oates.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I call'd you in to anſwer my queſtion, as to ſomewhat what is paſt, and to give your judgment how you are inclin'd to believe now.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Nay, but with your favour, it was to declare what opinion the Houſe of Lords had of you; and he ſays very well, and that is in truth the ſame anſwer that muſt be given, for the Judges and the Juries that try'd the People upon your Evidence: ſays my Lord of Huntingdon at firſt, truly I did believe Mr. Oates did ſwear true, and he had credit with me, and ſo he had with others; But now upon further Examination into things, and in proceſs of time Diſcoveries have been made of the truth, and that what he ſwore, is falſe; ſo that now I believe in my Conſcience he is actually forſworn, and has drawn innocent Blood upon the Nation; and no body will believe a word he ſays.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Well my Lord, I have done with my Lord of Huntingdon.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Withens.
sp.p: And he has done with you, as I perceive.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Yes, truly methinks ye ſhake hands and part very fairly.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Holloway.
sp.p: There's my Lord Chief Baron; what ſay you to him Mr. Oates?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Is my Lord Chief Baron ſworn?

sp.speaker: Cryer.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, he is.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Then what do you ask him?

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I call'd your Lordſhip, becauſe your Lordſhip ſate as a Commiſſioner of Oyer and Terminer in the Old-Bayly, at Ireland, Whitebread and Langhorn's Tryals; and that which I call your Lordſhip for, is to give an account to my Lord and the Jury, of the ſatisfaction your Lordſhip received concerning the fullneſs and fairneſs of the Evidence then deliver'd by me in thoſe Tryals.

sp.speaker: L. C. Baron.
sp.p: My Lord, I cannot charge my memory with it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He ſays he cannot remember.

sp.speaker: L. C. Baron.
sp.p: No not in particular; but in general I remember there was a great many Perſons that gave Evidence in thoſe Tryals on the one ſide and the other: There were a great many Perſons that came from St. Omers, that gave Evidence there of Mr. Oates being at St. Omers, when he ſaid he was in Town.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: And what Credit were they of at that time, pray my Lord?

sp.speaker: L. C. Baron.
sp.p: I think they were Perſons of very good Credit; they were Gentlemen of good Families many of them.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Did the Jury believe them at that time?

sp.speaker: L. C. Baron.
sp.p: I cannot tell what the Jury did.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Nor is it any matter at all what they did: But I would ask you my Lord but one queſtion: Have you heard this Evidence that has been given here to day?

sp.speaker: L. C. Baron.
sp.p: No my Lord, I have not.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: If you had, I would then have ask'd you, whether you believe him now or not.

sp.speaker: L. C. Baron.
sp.p: Truly my Lord, I never had any great Faith in him, I do aſſure you, as to my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Withens.
sp.p: You hear what he ſays Mr. Oates; you had never any great Credit with him.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I am not at all concern'd at this; I value my ſelf more upon my own Innocency and Integrity, than any Man's good or bad Opinion whatſoever.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Ah! your innocency is very great!

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Then my Lord, I will conclude my Evidence.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, before Mr. Oates goes to ſumm up his Evidence, we have ſome other Evidence to give.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What ſay you Mr. Oates? will you call any other Witneſſes to this point?

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, if they bring any other Evidence, I hope I may have my turn to anſwer it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Ah! Truly, if they bring any new Evidence that you have not applied to already, God forbid, that you ſhould not be heard; but if it only gives an anſwer to the Evidence that has been given, then you muſt not retort on them: for they are to have the laſt word; but it is not fit withal, that you ſhould be denied any thing that is neceſſary or really of advantage to you.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: If they offer any new Evidence to my diſ-reputation, the queſtion is, whether I may have a time allotted me to make my defence againſt that Evidence.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Ah! Ah! In God's name by all means?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: This is the uſual method of Proceedings; but I would know if Mr. Oates has any more Witneſſes to Examine to this point, that he has examin'd to already.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I think I have no further Evidence at preſent, till I hear what they further ſay.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Then may it pleaſe your Lordſhip, and you Gentlemen of the Jury—

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: I hope when your Lordſhip ſumms up the Evidence, you'll remember what has been ſaid by the Witneſſes.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You may aſſure your ſelf, I will remember whatſoever has been ſaid on the one ſide and t'other, as near as I can: the Gentlemen of the Jury are Men of underſtanding, and I ſee they take Notes, and I'le give them all the aſſiſtance I can.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Truly my Lord, I have ſome more Witneſſes to the ſame purpoſe, if your Lordſhip pleaſe to ſpare time to hear them.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Ah! Ah! We ſit here to hear the Witneſſes, call whom you will.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Is my Lord Lovelace here.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I cannot tell, I do not ſee him here; but you did call my Brother Gregory, there he is, what ſay you to him?

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Mr. Baron Gregory was Speaker of the Houſe of Commons in one of the Weſtminſter Parliaments.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Swear my Brother Gregory, (which was done.)

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: I deſire your Honour would be pleas'd to give this Court and the Jury an account, you being Speaker of the Houſe of Commons, what credit I received there in that Houſe upon my diſcovery of the Popiſh Plot.

sp.speaker: Mr. B. Gregory.
sp.p: My Lord, that is a pretty general queſtion, it is not poſſible for me to remember the Proceedings in the Houſe of Commons ſo long ago.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But Brother, I tell you what he means by it: he would have you to anſwer this queſtion, whether he was of good credit in the Houſe of Commons or not.

sp.speaker: Mr. B. Gregory.
sp.p: I know not what anſwer to make about the credit he there had: any Member of the Houſe of Commons may give as good and better an account in that matter than I; and truly I do not remember that Mr. Oates was before the Barr of the Houſe when I was Speaker: I believe it was before I was Speaker, that he was Examined at the Commons Barr.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, he can remember nothing of it.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Is my Lord Lovelace there?

sp.speaker: Crier.
sp.p: He has been call'd, but he is not here.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Call my Lord of Stamford.

sp.speaker: Crier.
sp.p: He is not here.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Call Sir Francis Winnington.

sp.speaker: Crier.
sp.p: He is not here.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Call Silas Titus Eſq

sp.speaker: Crier.
sp.p: He is not here.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Call Sir George Treby.

sp.speaker: Crier.
sp.p: He is not here.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Call Sir Francis Pemberton: Theſe have been all Subpoena'd.

sp.speaker: Crier.
sp.p: He is not here.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Is my Lord Biſhop of London?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Here is my Lord Biſhop of London, pray ſwear my Lord Biſhop of London; (which was done.)

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p:
I beg your Lordſhip, if you can, would give an account of your remembrance in this matter: your Lordſhip was often in Committees of the Houſe of Peers about this buſineſs, and from firſt to laſt, you were in the Committee for further Examination of the Popiſh Plot; And you were not only of the Committee, but you alſo ſate as a Baron in the Houſe.
I humbly beg your Lordſhip would pleaſe to tell as far as you can charge your Memory, what Reputation I had in the Houſe of Lords, where I was upon my Oath, and in particular, whether your Lordſhip remembers that I received the thanks of the Houſe for the Service I had done for the King and Kingdom in the Diſcovery.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Holloway.
sp.p: It is a long queſtion my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. B. of London.
sp.p: It is ſo my Lord; but my anſwer will be very ſhort: for it is a very little I can remember after ſo great a diſtance of time, and the tranſactions have been publick; nor can I acquaint the Court with any thing, but what is known already; and that is this, I remember that the Plot was diſcovered by him, and his diſcovery was receiv'd as Evidence at the Barr of the Houſe of Lords, and believ'd, and the thanks of the Houſe were given him at that time for it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: There's Sir George Treby, What do you ask him? but firſt let him be ſworn? (which was done.)

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray be pleas'd to ask Sir George Treby, who was Chair-man of the Committee of Secrecy, and was manager in the Trial of the Lord Viſcount Stafford, that he will be pleas'd to tell what Credit I had in both Houſes upon that Trial.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I told you before, you muſt urge nothing of that Trial, unleſs you have the Record-here.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Then my Lord, I deſire Sir George may give an account what he knows of the correſpondencies between Mr. Coleman and the See of Rome.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: No, that will not be any Evidence at all in this caſe; for that is not at all here in queſtion.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Then my Lord, I deſire Sir George Treby may ſpeak what he knows of my Credit in the Houſe of Commons.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Ah! What ſays he to that?

sp.speaker: Sir George Treby.
sp.p: My Lord, I can anſwer for nothing but my own Judgment; I cannot tell what Credit he had with any particular Member of the Houſe of Commons; I do remember indeed, he was there ſeveral times at the Barr, but not upon Oath, but as others uſually are there, and concerning the diſcovery: there was a Vote all the Kingdom knows of, that they were ſatisfied there was a Plot, but whether that Vote was grounded altogether upon his Evidence, or how far upon his Evidence, I cannot tell, nor what any Man thought of it beſides my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: I deſire Mr. Serj. Pemberton might be call'd again.

sp.speaker: Crier.
sp.p: He is not here.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Then pray call Sir William Dolben.

sp.speaker: Crier.
sp.p: He is not here neither.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Then I call Sir Edward Atkins.

sp.speaker: Crier.
sp.p: He is not here.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Call Mr. Richard White.

sp.speaker: Crier.
sp.p: He is not here.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, theſe were all Subpoena'd, but they will not come; they are frighted away.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: We know nothing of that, they may come if they will.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Call Mr. Thomas Cox.

sp.speaker: Crier.
sp.p: He is not here, but here is Mr. White.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: I pray he may be ſworn, (which was done) I deſire to know of him whether he were not a Jury man upon the Trials of Ireland and Whitebread.

sp.speaker: Mr. White.
sp.p: No, I was not.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Then I am miſtaken, I beg your pardon for this trouble.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, there's my Brother Dolben come now. What ſay you to him? Swear my Brother Dolben? (which was done.)

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: May it pleaſe you Sir William Dolben, you ſate as a Judge upon the Trials of Mr. Ireland, Mr. Whitebread and Mr. Langhorn; and I call you, Sir William Dolben, to give an account to my Lord and the Jury, what Credit my Evidence had at thoſe Tryals, and how the Jury was ſatisfied with it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: There is the Verdict man, that finds the Perſons you ſpeak of Guilty.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: If that be Evidence enough, I am ſatisfied my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Is not that better than his Opinion to ſhow how the Jury was ſatisfied; Ah! certainly better than the Opinion of all the twelve Judges; for that point they would not have Convicted them, except they had been ſatisfied with the Evidence.

sp.speaker: Sir William Dolben.
sp.p: Have you done with me Sir?

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: I have Sir.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Have you call'd all your Witneſſes, or will you call any more?

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: No my Lord, I will call no more at preſent.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Then my Lord wee'l go on with another part of our Evidence. Gentlemen, you ſee Dr. Oates, to ſupport his Credit, has given two ſorts of Evidence; the one is, ſome Records of Tryals at the Old-Bayly, wherein he had the good hap to be believ'd: the other is ſeveral noble Perſons, and other Gentlemen, as to the Credit he has had given to hi • Evidence before. What they have ſaid, I ſhall not meddle with at all at this time, but leave the Obſervations that are to be made thereupon, till we come to ſumm up the Evidence for the King. But as to the firſt part of his Evidence, that is, as to the Records produced, and the Verdicts therein given, and the Opinions of the Judges, we have this to ſay in point of Evidence as an anſwer. 1. We ſhall produce to you, ſeveral Records, wherein he has not been believ'd; as that of Sir George Wakeman, and my Lord Caſtlemain; and not only ſo, but we ſhall actually prove that he was perjur'd in them; that what he ſwore againſt them was utterly falſe, and you will hear, this was not the firſt time that he had ſworn falſe: for • n an Accuſation that he gave at a Tryal at Haſtings, we ſhall prove he ſwore Buggery upon a Perſon, which was prov'd falſe.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Can you produce any ſuch Record Mr. Attorney?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Yes, we ſhall.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do not interrupt the Kings Council; let them go on: you ſhall be heard quietly in your time.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſes.
sp.p: Nay, Mr. Oates need not be ſo haſty to ask for the Records, by degrees we ſhall produce Records enough againſt him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: We ſhall prove alſo by the Journals of the Lords Houſe, that he did forſwear himſelf: for after he had there made a long Narrative of the Plot, being askt whether he had any more to accuſe, than thoſe Perſons that he had nam'd, and this upon his Oath; he did there ſwear that he had no more Perſons to accuſe.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: That were Members of that Houſe, it was.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Sir, you muſt be quiet till they have done.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: But ſoon after he bethought himſelf, and accuſes the Queen and His Royal Highneſs the Duke, our now preſent Sovereign, of being in the Plot.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: What Plot did I accuſe them of?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Nay, you muſt ſit down and be quiet; how now, will you not let the Kings Council ſpeak? you were heard quietly, and ſo ſhall they be too.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Well my Lord, I will be quiet.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att Gen.
sp.p: Theſe things, my Lord, will ſhow of what Credit he was of at that time: Another thing we ſay to theſe Records, is this; There were two other Witneſſes, Mr. Clay and Mr. Smith, beſides thoſe that were now produced, which were the home Witneſſes, that did poſitively ſwear, that in April and May 78. Oates was here in Town: he did then indeed make uſe of thoſe other canting Witneſſes, for I cannot call them any otherwiſe, that beat ſo about the Buſh, and ſpeak of uncertainties, and contradict one another; but thoſe that I name, Clay and Smith, were home Witneſſes, and there lay the Credit of his being in Town, when the Witneſſes which came from St. Omers, ſay he was beyond Sea.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I beg I may ask one thing; whether my Lord Biſhop of London be there ſtill?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: No, my Lord of London is gone.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: I am ſorry for it, becauſe he could have given an account of this Smith, for he knows him.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I cannot help it, you ſhould have deſir'd him to ſtay while he was here; go on Mr. Attorney.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p:
I will my Lord; and this which I am going to ſay, as an anſwer to his Evidence, which will give a full anſwer to that other Objection which he made, which was, what was the Reaſon, when he had given ſuch an Evidence ſo long ago, it ſhould be delayed ſo long e're it was proſecuted. I'le give your Lordſhip a Reaſon and a ſatisfactory one, till thoſe Diſcoveries were made that have lately been made: The Evidence theſe Witneſſes gave, carried a probability of truth in it; and Sir Richard Barker himſelf added his Teſtimony to it, tho he does not think fit now to come and confirm it: I ſay hitherto it had ſome ſemblance of truth, and ſo did ballance the other Teſtimony of them that came from St. Omers: But when we had diſcover'd that it could be teſtified by twenty Perſons, that had not been at any of the former Tryals, that he was certainly all that time at St. Omers; and when we had diſcover'd the Tampering and Practices of Mr. Oates, in Suborning theſe Witneſſes to ſwear as corruptly as he ſwore at firſt; which we ſhall ſhow you palpably to be true that he did ſo; that gave us encouragement to go on to make enquiry into the matter; but this was not diſcover'd till half a year ago, or thereabouts. Now as to one of thoſe Witneſſes, that is Mr. Clay, the caſe ſtands thus; indeed I expected he would have brought
the ſame Witneſſes he did then; for I preſume they are all about Town, but he has not thought fit to do that: This Clay was then a Prieſt, and a Priſoner in the Gate-houſe for that very reaſon as being accuſed for being a Romiſh Prieſt; while he was there a Priſoner, Mr. Oates comes and threatens him, and ſollicits him to ſwear that he was here in Town in May 78. that he might be provided with proof againſt what the Boys of St. Omers (as he call'd them) would come to teſtifie; and threaten'd him if he did not, he would hang him, for he could ſwear him to be a Prieſt; and this was about three or four days before the Tryal of the Five Jeſuits: At length they came to a Bargain and Agreement, as you will hear, that he ſhould come and ſwear this; when Mr. Oates cannot pretend that the Evidence of Clay was known at all by any of the Committees that were concern'd in the management of his Diſcovery; or that he was ſo much as though of for a Witneſs. But we ſhall prove how it came to paſs; and I believe, if Mr. Oates would call him now, (as I do not queſtion he knows where to have him) Clay would not be ſo hardy now, as to affirm his former Teſtimony. Then as for Mr. Smith, his Caſe ſtands thus: Mr. Oates had ſworn him into the Plot, as you will find in his Narrative that he gave in upon Oath, which is upon Record, and enter'd in the Journals of the Lords Houſe. He was a School-Maſter in Iſlington, and Oates ſwears High Treaſon againſt him; and thereupon Warrants went out to take this Smith, and Mr. Oates was very violent in the purſuit of him but two or three days before the Tryal; and then, when all theſe Witneſſes from St. Omers were come, as he knew very well, he was in ſome doubt his deſign would have fail'd, and then does he prevail with Smith to become a Witneſs for him. And 'tis evident he did tamper with him, from that which was done by him at that time: For now he gives him under his hand, (to ſhew the Impudence, as well as Villany of the man) as it has been evident enough in all his carriage) a Paper that ſhould give him Authority to go free from all Proceſs and Arreſts upon any Warrants; and this Protection under Mr. Oates hand, is directed to all the Kings Officers, thereby commanding them to take notice that this Mr. Smith, whom before he had accus'd of being in the Plot, was an honeſt man, and employed in great Service for the King at that time. This Paper, when produc'd, will ſhow the time when it was made; and then it will appear, that two days after Smith comes and Swears that he din'd with him the firſt Monday in May in 78. This was what Smith ſwore then; and upon my mentioning of this Practice, if he have any ſhame in him, it muſt put him in ſome confuſion: for we are prepar'd to prove by undeniable Teſtimony, that Mr. Oates did not dine with this Mr. Smith that day: we ſhall prove it by the whole Family; but the firſt time ever Mr. Oates came there, was in July after, when he came into England from St. Omers, which theſe Witneſſes ſay, was the latter end of June. Then it was that he was with Mr. Smith, and came to his Houſe, and not before. And we ſhall prove by ſeveral Witneſſes, that upon the queſtions being asked of Mr. Smith, how he came to teſtifie ſuch a thing, his anſwer was, I muſt have died for it, if I had not don't, 'twas only a miſtake in point of time: But he threatned me, and ſo did ſome others too, that he would have me hang'd for being in the Plot, if I did not comply with him, and ſwear this for him. My Lord, I ſhall offer this Evidence that I have open'd, and then I hope we ſhall ſatisfie the Jury, and all that hear this Tryal, that he is one of the moſt notorious Villains that liv'd upon the Earth; to be ſure that ever was known in this Kingdom.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Firſt my Lord, wee'l produce our Records, where is the Record of Sir George Wakeman.

sp.speaker: Mr. Swift.
sp.p: This is the Record of Sir George Wakeman, and this is a true Copy, I examin'd it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Pray Sir Samuel Aſtry, read a word or two of it.

sp.speaker: C. Crown.
sp.p: Here is an Indictment againſt Sir George Wakeman for High Treaſon, he pleaded not Guilty; and here is an Acquittal by the Jury.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: He being acquitted, I deſire he may be ſworn, (which was done.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Pray Sir George Wakeman, was Mr. Oates ſworn againſt you at the Tryal?

sp.speaker: S. G. Wakeman.
sp.p: Yes Mr. Sollicitor, he was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Do you remember what he ſwore againſt you at that Tryal?

sp.speaker: S. G. Wakeman.
sp.p: Yes, I do Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Was that true that he ſwore, by the Oath you have taken?

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Is that a fair queſtion? I deſire the opinion of the Court.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Ah! Why not?

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: He was legally accus'd; he cannot ſwear himſelf off.

sp.speaker: L.C. J.
sp.p: But he is legally acquitted to, we have a Record for that here.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Ah! My Lord, he was acquitted, it's well known how.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Come Sir, was that he ſwore againſt you at your Trial true?

sp.speaker: Sir G. Wakeman.
sp.p: 'Twas falſe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What do you ſay Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir G. Wakeman.
sp.p: 'Twas falſe upon my Oath, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: What particulars did he ſwear againſt you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Pollexfen.
sp.p: Ah! Pray tell the particulars as near as you can what he ſwore againſt you.

sp.speaker: Sir G. Wakeman.
sp.p: My Lord, if your Lordſhip pleaſe, I will give a little account what he ſwore againſt me before the King and Council.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: That will not do Sir George Wakeman, we do not ask you that.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: No, it muſt be only the Evidence that was given upon this Acquittal, which is the Record here produc'd before us, what did he ſwear againſt you then?

sp.speaker: Sir G. Wakeman.
sp.p: He ſwore at that Trial as near as I can remember, that I undertook for a certain Summ of Money, 15000 l. as I think it was to poyſon the King, and I was to do it by the means of the Queen. I was to provide this Poyſon by for her, and ſhe was to give it to the King. This he ſwore at my Trial, which God forbid it ſhould be true; nothing can be more falſe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I ask you by the Oath you have taken, you are now quitted, and ſo in no danger; and being upon your Oath, ought to ſpeak the truth without malice or ill will to him that did accuſe you; was that he ſwore true or falſe?

sp.speaker: Sir G. Wakeman.
sp.p: Falſe, falſe, upon my Oath; I ſpeak it without any malice againſt the Man in the World.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Then ſwear my Lord Caſtlemain, (which was done.)

sp.speaker: Sir G. Wakeman.
sp.p: My Lord, I'le be bound to make it appear, that all he ſwore againſt me was falſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: And ſo was it he ſwore againſt my Lord Caſtlemain and others that were acquitted at the ſame time with Sir George Wakeman.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Firſt read the Record of my Lord Caſtlemain's Acquittal.

sp.speaker: C. Crown.
sp.p: Here is the very Record it ſelf: It was in this Court my Lord Caſtlemain was Indicted of High Treaſon, and Tried and Acquitted.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord Caſtlemain, pray what did Oates ſwear againſt you at your Trial and pray tell the Court whether that was true or falſe.

sp.speaker: E. of Caſtlemain.
sp.p: My Lord, as near as I remember, Mr. Oates did ſwear at my Trial, that he met me in Lincolns-Inn-fields, and that he went with me ſomewhere to Mr. Fenwicks Chamber in Dukes-ſtreet in Covent-garden, where he ſaid I did talk a great deal of Treaſon, and a great diſcourſe of that kind he ſaid there was, and he ſwore that I was in ſeveral Cabals in relation to the Kings death: I was afterwards acquitted by the Jury that Tri'd me, as appears by the Record; and here I do declare, as in the preſence of God, and with all the Imprecations of divine vengeance to fall upon me, if I ſpeak any thing but the truth, that not only that which he ſwore was falſe, but that I never had any thoughts in my heart, much leſs did ever declare in my words of any injury or hurt againſt the late King. And beſides, that I never ſaw the face of Oates in my life, till after I was put in Priſon upon his accuſation of me.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire to know what Religion that Noble Lord is of?

sp.speaker: E. of Caſtlemain.
sp.p: I am a Roman Catholick my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: We all know what Religion my Lord is of, you need not ask that queſtion.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: That's not the point my Lord, I muſt have declar'd in Evidence.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I wonder to ſee any Man that has the face of a Man carry it at this rate, when he hears ſuch an Evidence brought in againſt him.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: I wonder that Mr. Attorney will offer to bring this Evidence, Men that muſt have malice againſt me —

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Hold your Tongue; you are a ſhame to Mankind.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: No, my Lord, I am neither a ſhame to my ſelf or Mankind: what I have ſworn is true, and I will ſtand by it to my laſt breath, and ſeal it if occaſion be with my Blood.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: 'Twere pitty but that it were to be done by thy Blood.

sp.speaker: Oates,
sp.p: Ah! Ah! my Lord, I know why all this is, and ſo may the World very eaſily too.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Such impudence and impiety was never known in any Chriſtian Nation.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: But this will not do the work to make the Plot to be disbelieved; things are not to be done by great noiſes: I will ſtand by the truth.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Can you think to out-face ſuch Evidence as this with your Impudence?

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: But I hope you'l give me leave to make my defence.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Then carry your ſelf as becomes you in the Court.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I will do ſo.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: If you do not, we know how to make you do it, you ſhall not think to Domineer here.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I hope I do behave my ſelf as I ought.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: No, You do not.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Ill Language may provoke any Mans Paſſion my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Keep your ſelf within bounds, and you ſhall be heard; but we'll ſuffer none of your Extravagancies.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, If I had been aware of this, I could have produc'd Evidence that would have ſupported my Teſtimony in theſe matters.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Go on with your Proofs Mr. Attorney.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attorney.
sp.p: We will do ſo my Lord.

sp.speaker: E. of Caſtlemain.
sp.p: Have you done with me Sir?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Have you any other queſtions to ask my Lord Caſtlemain?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: No, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Then your Lordſhip may fit down again where you were.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Now my Lord, we ſhall ſhow the Lords Journal where it is Recorded, that he ſwore, he could accuſe no body elſe but thoſe that he nam'd, and then we ſhall give an account that ſoon after, he accus'd our preſent Soveraign, and the Queen Dowager.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Where is the Clerk of the Parliament.

sp.speaker: Mr. Swift.
sp.p: Here he is. Mr. Walker.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Swear him, (which was done.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Mr. Walker, is that the Journal of the Houſe of Lords.

sp.speaker: Mr. Walker.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, it is.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Deliver it in to the Clerk, and let him read it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Then you muſt direct to the time, or elſe it will be to no purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Swift.
sp.p: Sir Samuel Aſtry pray turn to Friday the 29th. of November 78.

div.p: C. of Crown Reads, Die veneris decimo nono Novembris 1678. Titus Oates being call'd in at the Barr, deſired to be heard a few words before he was ſworn—

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Mr. Attorney, I doubt this will not be Evidence: it is only a Paper of what he laid, taken before the Lords; but now whether that was upon Oath or no, is the queſtion, nay it appears it was not upon Oath; but ſays, it was before he was ſworn.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire it may be read all out.

div.p: C. Crown Reads, Titus Oates being call'd in at the Barr, deſir'd he might be heard a few words, before he was ſworn to ſpeak to the main buſineſs, which being granted to him, he complain'd of the reſtraint he is under, and being debarr'd of the liberty of his Friends coming to him, and of converſing with any body in private, and that no Engliſh-man ought to be reſtrain'd, unleſs accus'd by one or more Witneſſes; and pray'd that the reſtraint might be taken off, that he might be enabled to give his Evidence more cheerfully, and that the Houſe would be pleas'd to addreſs to the King for that purpoſe, and that his pardon may be renewed, becauſe he is under miſpriſion of Treaſon, to which the Lord Chancellour told him, that the Houſe would take his condition into conſideration, and then being ſworn, he was told by Lord Chancellour, that the Lords have received an Addreſs from the Houſe of Commons in part upon Evidence by him given there, and that the Houſe expects he ſhould give an account what that is, which has begot ſuch aſtoniſhment in the Houſe of Commons as is expreſſed in the Addreſs, upon which Titus Oates ſaid, that in July laſt, he ſaw a Letter from Sir George Wakeman —

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Is this Evidence Mr. Attorney?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, the uſe we make of it is to prove that he did accuſe the Queen.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What is the accuſation of the Queen to this purpoſe?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, we ſay he had ſworn ſeveral days before that he had no other perſons to accuſe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You ſhould produce that firſt that he ſwore ſo.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, we ſhould ſo, I think, and I thought it had been ſo done.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: This is no Evidence, for it is not upon Oath; it does not ſay ſo.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Yes, it does my Lord; but we will go on in order.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Come then, let us ſee what was ſworn about his having no more Perſons to accuſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray Sir Samuel Aſtry look the 30th. of October 78.

p.q: Die Mercurii 30. Octobris 1678. Titus Oates being call'd in, was ſworn at the Barr, and requir'd to anſwer to what he is now call'd in for concerning his diſcourſe with the Lord Anneſly laſt night, about the Duke of York.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I doubt this will not be Evidence neither; for we are now ſpeaking only about what ſhall be Evidence: We are not now medling with the methods of the Houſe in their Examination of Witneſſes, but what is Evidence here; ſuppoſe an Oath be adminiſtred to me for a particular purpoſe in the Houſe of Lords, that I ſhall anſwer to what is asked me concerning a diſcourſe that I had with a third perſon.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray Sir Sam. Aſtry look the next day; for there my Lord, he is examin'd upon the general.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: But firſt read the latter end of the former days Proceedings, beginning at thoſe words upon conſideration.

p.q: Upon conſideration of what Titus Oates had ſaid, he was call'd in again, and told by the Lord Chancellour that the Houſe has directed he ſhall be heard again to morrow at Nine a Clock, and the Lords do expect that by the Oath he hath now taken, he ſhould go thorow with what he hath to ſay, and therefore he ſhould prepare himſelf to deliver the whole truth of what he knows concerning the deſign againſt the Kings Perſon, and the Government of this Kingdom.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But ſtill Mr. Attorney, we are but where we were; for ſuppoſing upon my Examination upon Oath given me in the Houſe of Lords to a particular purpoſe, That my Lord Chancellor ſhould tell me here; my Lords intend to morrow, that you by vertue of the Oath now given you, ſhould come and give them ſatisfaction as to other queſtions, I doubt that would not be Evidence in Weſtminſter-hall: let us not ſtretch any thing further than it ſhould be upon any account whatſoever: for ſuppoſe I give you an Oath to make true anſwer to ſuch queſtions as I ſhall ask you concerning what was ſaid at the Seſſions-houſe at ſuch a Trial, and then I come after and ask you upon the Oath you have taken, what do you ſay concerning ſuch a buſineſs 7 Years ago, would that be Evidence?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: With ſubmiſſion my Lord, if a Man be told he is upon his Oath, to ſay all he knows of ſuch a deſign, what he ſays upon that Oath, is Evidence.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You ſay very true Mr. Attorney, if I give him a general Oath; but what he ſays concerning any other matter than that particular thing, which he was ſworn to give an account of, can never be Evidence.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Truly my Lord, I think we need not labour in ſuch a thing as this is.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Truly Mr. Sollicitour, I think it is no Evidence at all, if you can prove he was ſworn to his whole Narrative, and can bring any thing out of that, You ſay ſomething.

sp.speaker: M. Att. Gen.
sp.p: We deſire that my Lord of Berkley may be ſworn, (which was done.)

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What do you ask him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. G.
sp.p: Pray my Lord, will you give the Court and the Jury an account whether M. Oates was not ſworn to his Narrative, and deliver'd in his Evidence at your Lordſhips Barr upon Oath.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: My Lord of Berkley, let me ask you this queſtion, was every thing that he gave an account of at the Barr of the Lords Houſe, given in upon Oath?

sp.speaker: E. of Berkley.
sp.p: I cannot remember that my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: It is impoſſible that he ſhould.

sp.speaker: E. of Berkley.
sp.p: All I can teſtifie is but what I anſwered to the queſtion, which was asked me at my Lord Stafford's Trial.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But that is not material now my Lord, becauſe the Record of that Trial is not here.

sp.speaker: E. of Berkley.
sp.p: The ſame thing is entered here particularly.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, we deſire it may be read again.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Read it again with all my Heart.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: This is a particular Oath to a particular purpoſe; and ſhall I help it by intendment that he was afterwards ſworn to the general matter? No, I will not: ſuppoſe any thing had happen'd afterwards that it ſhould have been thought fit to proſecute Oates; Could the Man have been Convicted of Perjury for this? certainly he never could.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Well my Lord, we ſubmit it to you; but we will now go on to prove that which Mr. Attorney opened, that Oates did ſuborn theſe Witneſſes to ſwear what they did ſwear: you have had one part of the Evidence that was then given; now we ſhall prove that Clay was ſworn at Whitebreads Trial, and what he did there teſtify about Oates being in Town.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: I own it, he was ſworn then.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Do you own that you ſuborn'd him?

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: No, I think not Mr. Attorney.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Then we will prove that you did tamper with him, and by threatnings prevail'd with him to ſwear for you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Nay, we will prove that he was miſtaken in what he did ſwear a whole Year. Pray call Mr. Charles Howard.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire I may have leave to ask the Court a queſtion, and I beg the Opinion of the Court in it, whether a Popiſh Recuſant Convicted, may be a good Witneſs.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: We are not bound to anſwer your queſtion; for we ſee no ground why you ſhould ask it: if you have any occaſion to object againſt any Witneſs, and can produce any Record againſt him; then we will tell you more of our minds.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray then let me ask you another queſtion my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Prethee do not trouble us with thy queſtions, let them go on with their Evidence.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire to know whether a Man confeſſing himſelf a Popiſh Prieſt—

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: We do not ſit here to anſwer every idle queſtion; 'tis nothing at all to the purpoſe: When you ask a proper queſtion, we will anſwer it.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Yes, it is my Lord, and you are of my Council in matter of Law.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I am not ſo.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, the Court is always of Council for the Priſoner.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: That were well indeed, if we were bound to give advice in every caſe where a Man is Proſecuted at the Kings Suit; indeed in thoſe caſes where a Man can have no Council allow'd him, the Court is of Council for him; but where he may have Council, the Judges are not of Council for him.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Holloway.
sp.p: Beſides, We are not here putting of Caſes, but trying of a Cauſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Here is Mr. Charles Howard, ſwear him, (which was done.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, we bring this Gentleman Mr. Charles Howard only to this part of our Evidence, to prove that Mr. Clay was miſtaken a whole Year, miſtook 78 for 77.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But Mr. Sollicitor, if you take this confuſed method, we ſhall never be at an end, and for my part I cannot make any thing of it; it is impoſſible for me to retain theſe things in memorie, ſo as to give any direction to the Jury, if there be not a method uſed: for do you think that it is poſſible for any Man to retain in his head a hundred things hudled up and down without any order.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: We beg your Lordſhips patience but a little while, and we ſhall have it in very good order. Swear Higgins, (which was done.)

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Pray what do you ask him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: The matter we examine him to is this; for I would open to you the nature of our Evidence, 1. He ſwore Smith into the Plot, and then gave him a Certificate, that he vvas an honeſt Man.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Is that Oates's hand.

sp.speaker: M. Att. Gen.
sp.p: We ſhall prove it to be ſo.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You muſt firſt prove vvhat he ſwore of Smith.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, We deſire that vve may read his Narrative.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But firſt prove it Mr. Attorney.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: It is upon Record in the Houſe of Lords.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was that delivered in upon Oath to the Houſe of Lords, or elſe vve ſhall be but vvhere vve vvere.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: For proof of that vve call my Lord Bridgewater.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Here he is, ſwear my Lord, (which was done.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord Bridgewater, do you remember the Narrative that Oates gave in to the Houſe of Lords, and vvas it upon Oath? but firſt of all if you pleaſe, I deſire my Lord may ſee the Book, whether any thing be there under his hand, and then vvhether it be enter'd to be upon Oath, and vvhether this be the Journal agreeing with the Paper deliver'd in.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: This is a Narrative my Lord, that he himſelf deliver'd in, and I vvould ask my Lord Bridgewater this one queſtion: Was not this Journal compar'd vvith the Narrative given in upon Oath by Order of the Lords Houſe.

sp.speaker: E. Bridgewater.
sp.p: Yes, I muſt ſay I was one of the Committe appointed to take care of the Journal, and here is my hand to it among other Lords, and that is a Copy of what M. Oates did deliver in as his Narrative which was in inſerted upon a report of the Committe into the Journal Book by Order of the Lords, and we did examine the Narrative with the Book.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But what is all this to our purpoſe now; do not miſtake me my Lord Bridgwater, I do not ſpeak to you now, but to Mr. Attorney: What does this prove as to the matter in hand?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray my Lord Bridgwater, did you ſee the Narrative brought in by Oates?

sp.speaker: E. Bridgwater.
sp.p: That Narrative was delivered to us by the Clerk of the Parliament.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But my Lord, do you know that Narrative was given in upon Oath?

sp.speaker: E. Bridgwater.
sp.p: I know no other, but that the Clerk of the Parliament brought it to us.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Here is the Clerk of the Parliament, will tell you that Oates was ſworn to it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Prove it if you can; but hitherto I ſee nothing that looks like Evidence.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Really my Lord, I ſhould take it to be as much Evidence as any that ever was offer'd in the World.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Pray Mr. Attorney let us Reaſon the Point a little; ſuppoſe you bring an anſwer in Chancery; except the man be ſworn to it, can you read his anſwer; and yet I ever look'd upon an anſwer in Chancery as Evidence.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: In that caſe the Record proves it ſelf, and ſo it ſhould here; and therefore we deſire it may be read.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But ſurely you would not allow an anſwer to be Evidence, unleſs you prove it to be ſworn.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Truly my Lord I always took it, that we need not come to prove a man was actually ſworn to his anſwer; but if it be once enter'd upon Record in Chancery, it proves it ſelf.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: It is true Mr. Attorney, if it appears upon Record that the anſwer was ſworn.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, if this Journal of the Houſe of Lords is a Record, then that which is entred into it is a Record; 'tis a thing recorded as a Deed inrolled is, and proves it ſelf.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Mr. Attorney, either we miſtake one another, or we do not differ in opinion: if you could make it appear that Oates brought this thing in the Houſe of Lords, and deliver'd it upon Oath, that were Evidence; otherwiſe I cannot ſee how you can make Evidence of it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: I always thought my Lord, that a Record out of a Court of Record, would have that Credit in another Court of Record, as to be read.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: My Lord Bridgewater tells you, it was deliver'd to them by the Clerk of the Parliament.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray my Lord let the Clerk read what is at the end thereof.

p.q: Hitherto examin'd the third of December 1678. The Narrative and Examinations of Titus Oates, being firſt inſerted according to the Order of the Houſe, of the 21. of November laſt, by us Angleſey, &c.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray read the Order of the 21. of November.

p.q: Die Jovis 21. of November 1678. Upon Report made by the Earl of Bridgewater, from the Lords Sub-Committees for the examining the Journal of this Houſe; That upon Examination thereof, their Lordſhips find, that the Narrative made upon Oath by Titus Oates at the Barr on the 31. of October laſt, of the Horrid Deſign againſt His Majeſties Perſon and Government; is only mentioned in the Journal, but not enter'd at large in ſuch manner as he then related it; and that therefore their Lordſhips deſire, the direction of the Houſe concerning this matter: it is thereupon ordered, that the ſaid Narrative made by Titus Oates on the ſaid 31. of October, ſhall be enter'd at large, and inſerted in the Journal, as the part of the buſineſs of that day.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Now you make it Evidence; for it appears that he was ſworn, and gave his Narrative upon Oath.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Then now my Lord, I hope we may read it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Ay, read it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Read the 54. Article.

p.q: This is the Narrative of Titus Oates, the 54. Article. That one Matthew Medborne a Player in the Dukes Theatre; one Mr. Penny, Mr. Mannock, Mr. Sharpe, and Mr. Seddon, and one William Smith a School-maſter at Iſlington, and one Edward Everard and others, meeting in a Club on Thurſday nights, and Sunday nights, with one Jones a Prieſt, and one Keymaſh within mentioned; and all theſe Perſons are imployed by the Jeſuits, to vilifie the Houſe of Commons, and to go about the City to incenſe the People againſt them, and againſt the Biſhops of the Nation; and they deliver this Treaſonable Poſition, That the Commons aſſembled in Parliament, are the Devils Repreſentatives and not the Nations; with treaſonable and deteſtable words, the Deponent did hear at the ſaid Club which is kept at Fuller's Rents near Grey's Inn. And in the month of Auguſt the Deponent was ordered by the Jeſuits in London, to give the ſaid Perſons great Reſpects, and in their names to thank the Club for their faithfulneſs to them in that particular.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Thus you ſee what he had ſworn againſt him; now we ſhall ſhew how he dealt with him. Is that Mr. Oates his hand?

sp.speaker: Witneſs.
sp.p: It is; yes I believe it is.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: I believe he will hardly deny it himſelf.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Let me ſee it I pray you, Mr. Attorney.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Show it him, (which was done) is that your hand?

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: I cannot ſay it is my hand; nor do I believe it to be ſo.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He does not own it to be his hand.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: I do not ſay it is not my hand; but I do not remember any thing of it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Read it Sir, pray you.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What is it you would read?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: A Certificate under Oates hand of Mr. Smith's honeſty, not three days before the Tryal of the Five Jeſuits.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p:
Read it, let us hear what it is.
Theſe are to certifie that William Smith is no Papiſt; and that he is upon good Service at this time for his King and Country; of which, I hope, thoſe that are Inquirers after Recuſants will take notice.
Witneſs my Hand this Third day of June 1679.
Titus Oates.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What harm is there in all this? I muſt needs ſay, I cannot comprehend what you would make of it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: This Protection was given Mr. Smith by Mr. Oates three days before the Tryal; but after he had ſworn him into the Plot in his Narrative.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I ſee not any Plot, for my part, that he ſwore him into, unleſs you mean Treaſon againſt the Houſe of Commons: for that is the Accuſation he made, that he ſpoke ſuch words of the Houſe of Commons. Pray read it again. (Which was done.)

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, and what is all this?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Is not this a ſwearing him into the Plot?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: No, not that I ſee: it only gives an ill Character of him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: But he is accuſed as a Confederate with the Prieſts and Jeſuits.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Did I charge him, Mr. Attorney, with having any hand in the Plot againſt the Kings Life?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: I only offer this as an Evidence that there was tampering.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You call it a being in the Plot; I ſee no ſuch thing.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: And then he comes and gives him an acquittal under his hand, and then produces him as a Witneſs.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: There can be no great matter in this Mr. Attorney.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Then my Lord, we'l call Mr. Smith himſelf, and he will tell you how Oates drew him in: Swear Mr. Smith, (which was done) pray acquaint my Lord and the Jury, how you came to ſwear at the former Tryal; by whom you were perſwaded, and how you varied from the Truth.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: That is very nauſeous and fulſome Mr. Attorney, methinks in a Court of Juſtice.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What did you ſwear in the former Tryal? and was that true you did ſwear then?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I tell you truly Mr. Attorney, it looks rank and fulſome: if he did forſwear himſelf, why ſhould he ever be a Witneſs again?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: 'Tis not the firſt time by twenty that ſuch Evidences has been given.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I hate ſuch Preſidents in all times; let it be done never ſo often. Shall I believe a Villain one word he ſays, when he owns that he forſwore himſelf?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray my Lord give me leave; I muſt purſue my Maſters Intereſt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, it was ever Teſtimony allow'd to be given, to detect a Subornation.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I am ſure 'tis not fit to be allow'd at any time: If he did forſwear himſelf in a Court of Record, in my opinion he is not to be receiv'd as a Witneſs any more.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: We do only make this uſe of him, to prove that Oates did ſuborn him.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Pray call ſome other Witneſſes, if you have them, to contradict him; but do not offer to bring a man to ſwear that he did forſwear himſelf before.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, we give Evidence here of a mans being produc'd by Oates, to ſwear he was here in May 78. and he did make ſuch an Oath: now I hope, with Submiſſion my Lord, it is Evidence to contradict that Oath, if we can prove that he has confeſſed he was forſworn, and miſtaken in his Oath; ſuch Evidence perhaps will be of little value, yet Evidence it is.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Make it what you will, Mr. Sollicitor; I think it is of no value at all, nor to be admitted for the man to come and ſwear it himſelf: prove what you can by others.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Surely my Lord, this Confeſſion of his to others is of leſs value, than when we bring the Man himſelf to confeſs his fault; that Man himſelf coming and owning the thing, that he was miſtaken, with great ſorrow for it, ſure is a good Evidence.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſtice.
sp.p: Argue the matter as long as you will, Mr. Sollicitor, you will never convince me, But that he that has once forſworn himſelf, ought not to be a witneſs after that in any Caſe whatſoever. If any man tell me otherwiſe till Dooms-day, I cannot be convinc'd of it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: I go but to ask him this Queſtion, Whether or no what he ſwore were true?

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſtice.
sp.p: Mr. Sollicitor, we are all of another Opinion, that it is not Evidence fit to be given.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, I muſt ſubmit it to you.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſtice.
sp.p: I tell you, Mr. Sollicitor, if you ſhould call him to know what it was he ſwore, and it does appear by any Evidence, or by his own Confeſſion, that it was falſe, you ought not to believe what he ſays even in that matter. And I think truly, for examples ſake, it ought not by any means to be admitted.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sollicitor.
sp.p: My Lord, I muſt ſubmit it to you, but then I humbly conceive, it will be in very many Caſes impoſſible to detect a Perjury or Subornation, if the Party ſuborn'd cannot be admitted to be a witneſs.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſtice.
sp.p: What good will the admitting him to be a witneſs do? for either what he ſwore then, or what he ſwears now, is falſe; and if he once ſwears falſe, Can you ſay he is to be believed?

sp.speaker: Mr. North.
sp.p: My Lord, If a man come and ſwear —

sp.speaker: L. C. Justice.
sp.p: Look ye, Sir, you have our Opinion; it has been always the Practice heretofore, That when the Court have delivered their Opinion, the Council ſhould ſit down, and not diſpute it any further.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Then we will go about the Buſineſs of Clay, and for that we will call Lawrence Davenport.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſtice.
sp.p: 'Tis certainly againſt the Law to admit a man that has once forſworn himſelf to be a witneſs again in any Cauſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att Gen.
sp.p: Swear Lawrence Davenport. (which was done) 'Pray' give my Lord and the Jury an account how Clay came to be a witneſs, and by whom he was wrought upon to be ſo.

sp.speaker: Davenport.
sp.p: May it pleaſe you, my Lords and Gentlemen of the Jury, Mr. Oates came to the Priſon, I being then a Priſoner at that time in the Gate-houſe at Weſtminſter my ſelf, and having no other Employment, I had the government and care of ſome of the Priſoners for a livelihood, being in cuſtody; and at that time Mr. Oates, as I ſaid, when old Clay was in Priſon, did come there to viſit this Clay at ſeveral times; and coming there to viſit this Clay, up ſtairs he went to his Chamber, and deſired to ſpeak with him; and I did deſire your Worſhip, Mr. Oates, that you would go in to him, and you did go into his Chamber, and there theſe words you did ſpeak to him before the Trial of the five Jeſuits, That if he did not ſwear what you put to him, he ſhould be proſecuted as a Prieſt, which you did believe he would dye for.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſtice.
sp.p: What is this man's name?

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſtice.
sp.p: Did you hear him ſay ſo?

sp.speaker: Davenport.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, upon my Oath I did hear him ſay ſo, and Sir William Waller was with him; and then he replied and ſaid, with a Proviſo, That you would give him his Gold and Silver that was taken from him, being then a Priſoner under My keeping in the Gate-houſe, and wanting his money; if you would do that, he ſaid, he had been a Rogue before, and he could not ſay what he might do.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſtice.
sp.p: Now make it appear that this Clay was ſworn at the Trial.

sp.speaker: Davenport.
sp.p: My Lord, afterwards I was Keeper to him under the other Keeper, and he had a Keeper to wait on him to Newgate Seſſions at the Old Baily; wherefore this Gentleman that is ſtanding there, Mr. Oates, comes to us, ſays he, Do not you trouble your ſelf about this Priſoner; let him alone with me, I'll ſee him at home again; and then the Jeſuits there did take their Trials: how it was I cannot tell; for we could not come into the Court: afterwards they went to the Fountain Tavern by Newgate to Dinner, and Mr. Oates and he went to Dinner together; we were below in the houſe waiting there till it was Night, and ſtill thinking that he ſhould come down again; but away went he home, and left us in the lurch; but indeed he did come home to the Priſon very honeſtly and civilly, becauſe he was civilly guarded.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Now, my Lord, we'll give you an account, That the next morning after this Diſcourſe betwixt Oates and Clay at the Gate-houſe, this witneſs told it to another that was a Priſoner there then too.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I would ask this man a Queſtion, Whether he had the ſole keeping of Clay without any other Keeper with him.

sp.speaker: Davenport.
sp.p: There was no Keeper in the houſe, but my ſelf, where he lay, which was in Margaret's Lane, not in the Priſon, but in the Houſe.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: 'Pray' ask this Gentleman, why he did not come in and teſtifie this Diſcourſe, he ſpeaks of, when Clay was a witneſs.

sp.speaker: Davenport.
sp.p: I was not by when he was ſworn.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Did he not know he was a witneſs?

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſtice.
sp.p: No, he ſays he did not go into the Court with you, he was not ſuffered to go in.

sp.speaker: Davenport.
sp.p: My Lord, I am a poor Trandeſman, and know nothing what belongs to the Law.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Come, 'pray' ſwear this man, Mr. — (which was done.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: 'Pray' tell what Davenport told you, and when.

sp.speaker: Mr. —
sp.p: He came and told me the next day in the Priſon, where I was then, what Mr. Oates, and Sir William Waller had been tampering with Clay about, to make him ſwear for Mr. Oates.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſtice.
sp.p: What were the words he told you they ſaid to him?

sp.speaker: Mr. —
